In addition to housing and office space, this new district, scheduled for completion in 2021, is already brimming with clothing boutiques, concept stores, cafes and restaurants, many devoted to native Swiss designers and delicacies. title: The Misunderstood Genius of Russell Westbrook
description: In Philadelphia, before the first game of the N.B.A. season, Russell Westbrook worked through his warm-up routine. He was loose and laughing but  as always  precise. Westbrooks internal clock had driven him to be the first player out on the court, a full three hours before tipoff, and he was performing his routine in front of a largely empty arena. He started with chip-ins and free throws, easy stuff to get his body going, and then moved on to his signature shot: the pull-up jumper. Westbrooks pull-up is one of modern basketballs most recognizable weapons  if not yet quite on the level of Kareems skyhook or Jordans turnaround or Dirks one-legged fadeaway, then at least at the edge of that territory. The move is a surprise attack. Westbrook is unreasonably fast and aggressive, a flying, screaming whirlwind of ferocious highlight dunks, and he charges the hoop with so much raging menace that defenders have no choice but to scramble backward to try to stop him. Thats when he hits them with the pull-up: He stops instantly and  while the defenders momentum continues to drag him backward  leaps perfectly straight into the air, like a fighter pilot ejecting from his cockpit to escape an explosion, except that Russell Westbrook is the explosion: He is the explosion and the control all at once. The whole thing seems to defy the laws of motion. Growing up in Los Angeles, Westbrook practiced this move so many tens of thousands of times on the playground that he and his father referred to it as the cotton shot, because they always expected it to go through the net.

title: What to Do About a Co-Worker Who Drinks on the Job?

She is the only one of our small group who drinks alcohol at lunch; others of our group find this behavior quite odd or even outright wrong. I have not said anything to my co-worker about this and have written it off as a peculiarity. But now I have learned that she is drinking surreptitiously at her desk in the afternoon. I have no way of knowing how intoxicated she is when she leaves the office, but I believe that she drives herself home at least a few days a week.

title: A Rare Pacific Islander Captivates Its Neighborhood
description: TAVEUNI ISLAND, Fiji  In Fiji, flowers can take on a spiritual, magical significance. They are strung together as garlands for ceremonies and festivals or worn as an ornament behind the ear on any given day.

description: Kirill Gerstein plays from a new critical edition of Tchaikovskys Piano Concerto No. 1, with James Gaffigan conducting the Deutsches Symphonie-Orchester Berlin.

description: BARCELONA, Spain  President Trumps travel ban disrupted the plans of hundreds of people around the globe, but perhaps none more vulnerable than Sham Aldaher, a Syrian refugee girl, and her family.

description: Q. My phones camera has taken blurry photos since I dropped it. Is there a way to repair the camera, or do I need to get a new phone?

title: Bacon Shortage? Calm Down. Its Fake News.
description: The alarming headlines came quickly Wednesday morning: Now Its Getting Serious: 2017 Could See a Bacon Shortage. Nations bacon reserves hit 50-year low as prices rise. Everyone Freak Out! American Is Running Low on Bacon.

description: A new website features the photojournalism of hundreds of women.

title: Highlighting Women in Photojournalism
description: In 1973, Sara Krulwich visited 29 newspapers, looking for a job after graduating from the University of Michigan. She met with male photo editors who mostly scoffed at the idea of a woman as a news photographer. One editor, she said, told her that hiring a woman was like hiring half a person.

title: U.N. Leader Says Trump Visa Bans Violate Our Basic Principles
description: UNITED NATIONS  The new secretary general of the United Nations said on Wednesday that the Trump administrations visa bans for citizens of seven Muslim-majority nations violate our basic principles and would do little to stem the threat of terrorism.

title: What Volkswagen Settlements Mean for Vehicle Owners
description: Volkswagen has agreed to pay more than $20 billion to settle civil and criminal suits in the United States over its diesel emissions scandal, affecting almost 600,000 cars. This is what that could mean for vehicle owners:

title: Daily Report: At Apple, Triumphs Amid Tribulations
description: Lets face it: Just about any boss on the planet would like to have the problems of Tim Cook, Apples chief executive.

description: Sampha, the experimental British pop singer and electronic producer, sounds like someone who has seen things.

description: Think you know Tchaikovskys Piano Concerto No. 1? Think again.

title: Germany, the Euro, and Currency Manipulation
description: Peter Navarro, the closest thing Trump has to an economic guru, made some waves by accusing Germany of being a currency manipulator and suggesting that both the shadow Deutsche mark and the euro are undervalued. Leaving aside the dubious notion that this is a good target of US economic diplomacy, is he right?

title: Jeff Sessions Approved as Attorney General by Senate Committee
description: WASHINGTON  A divided Senate Judiciary Committee approved the nomination of Senator Jeff Sessions as attorney general Wednesday, despite a fierce pushback from Democrats over President Trumps firing this week of the Justice Departments acting chief, who had objected to the administrations refugee policy.

title: The Real People of J. Crew, Diors Artsy Side and an Exhibit on Body Art
description: Matthew Usukumah, an assistant planner at J. Crew, never thought he would be a model. But he will find himself on view at the brands presentation Feb. 12 alongside other real people cast for the show. Here, we get a look at what hell be wearing: a slouchy camel topcoat and crisp striped shirt under a Fair Isle sweater.

title: Review: Powerless on NBC Has Cubicles, Not Capes
description: Look! Up on the screen! Its a mystery! Its a sitcom! Oh, and its a superhero show!

title: Theresa May Gets Parliaments Backing on Brexit Bill
description: LONDON  Easily winning a crucial vote among lawmakers, Prime Minister Theresa May was well on her way Wednesday to winning the parliamentary approval that Britains highest court said she needed before she could begin talks on ending more than four decades of European integration.

title: A Personal Trainer for Heartbreak
description: After a traumatic breakup, Julia Scinto, a fashion designer in Manhattan, found herself searching online sites far and wide, looking for any available resource to help her feel better.

title: Evaluating Trumps Nomination of Judge Gorsuch to the Supreme Court: A Lesson Plan
description: President Trump on Jan. 31 nominated Judge Neil M. Gorsuch to the Supreme Court, elevating a conservative in the mold of Justice Antonin Scalia to succeed the jurist, who died last year, and touching off a brutal, partisan showdown at the start of his presidency over the ideological bent of the nations highest court.

description: If you made a New Years resolution, theres an 80 percent chance youve already given it up or youre just about to. But thats O.K.! We want to help you stick with it  or revamp it into something you really want to achieve. So for February, Smarter Living will offer tips, advice and motivation.

description: Good morning.

title: A New Beachside Bungalow to Book
description: Jocelyne Sibuet, who has brought her inimitable style to chalets from the Riviera to the Alps, makes her Caribbean debut with Villa Marie Saint-Barth. Set in the shell of the old Franois Plantation hotel, the propertys 21 hillside bungalows look out to the sandy inlet of Flamands Beach. St. Barthlemy is where Sibuet most likes to vacation with her family, and so she named the new spot after her daughter, who helped with the interior design. Together they hunted for touches justes, which include Pierre Frey palm-printed textiles and the antique rattan armchairs that sit on the rum bars breezy terrace.

title: Meant to Resettle Refugees, An Empty Home
description: A refugee family from Myanmar expected to move into a house in St. Paul, Minn., this month. Furnished and full of toys, it will sit empty for a while. Look inside.

title: Better Deals on Homes Can Chase Away Winter Doldrums
description: February typically isnt a month that brings out hordes of home shoppers. Colder weather and postholiday belt-tightening often combine to push sales into the doldrums.

title: 2 G.O.P. Senators to Vote Against Betsy DeVos as Education Secretary
description: WASHINGTON  Two Republican senators on Wednesday said they would vote against President Trumps nominee for education secretary, delivering a blow to the White House and raising the possibility that Vice President Mike Pence would have to break a tie to win her confirmation.

title: N.L.R.B. Lawyer Sees Some College Football Players as Employees, With Rights
description: Top-level college football players at private universities are employees entitled to request improved working conditions and even to seek pay for their efforts, according to a memorandum issued by the general counsel for the National Labor Relations Board and made public on Tuesday.

title: Beyonc Is Pregnant With Twins
description: That collective shriek of joy youre hearing from the BeyHive? Beyonc and Jay Z are expecting twins.

title: Finding the Speed of Evolution in a Study of Bird Beaks
description: When the ancestors of Darwins finches arrived on the Galpagos two million years ago, they gained access to a world of new morsels, untapped by other animals. In a relatively short period, 14 species of finches evolved, specializing in different diets through different beak shapes: short for crushing seeds, sharp for catching insects, long for probing cactus flowers and so on.

title: Rex Tillerson Is Confirmed as Secretary of State Amid Record Opposition
description: WASHINGTON  Rex W. Tillerson, the former chairman and chief executive of Exxon Mobil, was confirmed by the Senate on Wednesday in a 56-to-43 vote to become the nations 69th secretary of state just as serious strains have emerged with important international allies.

title: The Ovadia Twins Play to a Home Crowd
description: The twin designers Shimon and Ariel Ovadia, the Brooklyn-bred men behind the label Ovadia & Sons, played before an enthusiastic hometown crowd on Tuesday, the second night of New York Fashion Week: Mens.

title: Neil Gorsuch and the Search for the Supreme Court Mainstream
description: The declaration Tuesday night by Senator Chuck Schumer, the leader of Senate Democrats, that the burden is on Judge Neil Gorsuch to prove himself to be within the legal mainstream poses a crucial question: Where is todays mainstream?

title: A Volcano's Unabated Lava Flow
description: A stream of lava from the Kilauea volcano pours into the Pacific at the Kamokuna entry point, triggering explosions that throw bits of the molten substance back onto the top of the sea cliff.

title: Nautica: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: Peloton Instructors Ride for Fitness and Fame
description: Last year, Fred Klein spent a lot of time in group exercise classes in Manhattan, although replacing his love handles with rock-hard obliques was not his objective. Mr. Klein is the chief content officer for Peloton Cycle, a boutique fitness studio. He was seeking instructors to poach and hire.

title: Andrea Kleines New Work Focuses on Torture and Music
description: What do the Bee Gees, Metallica, Christina Aguilera and Barney the purple dinosaur have in common? Apparently, their songs have all been used as tools of torture by the United States military. In Andrea Kleines new work, My Dinner With Andrea: The Piece Formerly Known as Torture Playlist, pop songs mix with an original score by Bobby Previte as she and six other performers explore the overlap of choreographic and torture techniques  repetition, obsession, release  and confront societys complicity.

title: Merce Cunningham, Looking Beyond the Movement
description: Before Merce Cunningham died in 2009, he decided his dance company would die with him. So, in 2011, after a final tour, it did. Yet a wealth of his art remains in circulation. Other companies perform his dances, and this week two American museums will open surveys devoted to his dance-related work.

title: Israel Ejects Settlers in Last Stand at West Bank Synagogue
description: Hundreds of angry protesters confronted Israeli police officers as they tried to eject them Thursday from the illegal West Bank settlement of Amona, the second day of clashes there. Several officers were injured as they cleared a synagogue of 200 people who had barricaded themselves in the outposts last inhabited building.

title: Its Always Sunny Just Keeps Getting Bolder
description: Its Always Sunny in Philadelphia is in the midst of yet another outrageous season, its 12th, and on Wednesday night, Feb. 8, things get particularly ear-burning in an episode called Hero or Hate Crime? The series, on FXX, is about five friends who operate a bar in Philadelphia. The season premiere in January was pretty over the top  the five, who are white, were turned black by an electrical shock as they were watching The Wiz, and a semi-musical exploration of racial stereotyping ensued. The Feb. 8 installment is at least as boundary-pushing. It begins with a falling piano, a shouted gay slur and a windblown scratch-off lottery ticket. The five take their dispute over ownership of the ticket to professional arbiters, and the resulting debate about what does and does not constitute a slur would curl George Carlins toes. The episode also gives the props department a chance to make indescribably vulgar alterations to an exercise bicycle, and by its end one of the core five, Mac (Rob McElhenney), may have had a personal breakthrough 12 seasons in the making.

title: New Ways to Get Intimate
description: Underthings that suit you. And just in time for Valentines Day.

title: Texas Mayor Announces That She Is Transgender
description: Just days before a public town meeting on Tuesday night, Jess Herbst, the mayor of New Hope, Tex., had an official announcement.

title: A Full Carnegie Hall and More in the Northeast
description: Some nights it just happens: The musical world aligns to give listeners a burst of exciting offerings. Friday, Feb. 10, presents some tough choices for classical fans in the Northeast corridor. All three of Carnegie Halls performance spaces are filled. The extraordinary pianist Igor Levit makes his Carnegie debut in Zankel Hall with Beethovens Diabelli Variations, three prelude-fugue pairings by Shostakovich and a new work by Frederic Rzewski. Upstairs in the intimate Weill Hall, the charming soprano Anna Lucia Richter gives a recital of songs by Schumann, Brahms and Britten. And in the biggest room, Stern Auditorium, the American Symphony Orchestra under Leon Botstein delves into lesser-known 20th-century Czech works. (carnegiehall.org)

title: Two Young Cuban Jazz Players Arrive at the Standard
description: Alfredo Rodrguez and Pedrito Martnez both came to the United States from Cuba, where they grew up under different circumstances. Mr. Rodrguez, a pianist, was the son of a famous singer and became a star student at a Havana conservatory.

title: Corner Store Owner Denies Family Ties. All Five Families.
description: Take all the random stuff out of that dresser drawer where it tends to land, and all that stuffs distant cousins in the kitchen drawer, and the exotic little screws and bolts from the untouched corners of the toolbox. Put them all on shelves in a dark little room, add coolers stocked with beer, and declare everything for sale. Thats pretty much the business model at the Smith Union Market in Brooklyn.

title: Life According to Saki, in the Trenches of World War I
description: The Edwardian era never looked quite as beguilingly sinister as it did through the gimlet eyes of Hector Hugh Munro, better known by his pen name, Saki. Celebrated for short stories of filigree sentences and blood-freezing endings, Munro (1870-1916) is being reincarnated with suitably macabre elegance at the Fourth Street Theater, where Katherine Rundells Life According to Saki begins previews on Wednesday, Feb. 8. Directed by Jessica Lazar, this production (which took the Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh Award at last years Edinburgh Festival Fringe) places the dapper Munro in the trenches during World War I, where he entertains the lads with narratives that twist like a corkscrew. (His fellow Tommies assist in the tale-telling, as do some Bunraku puppets.) Evidently, that greatest of concluding Saki lines  Romance at short notice was her specialty  applied to its creator as well. (Through March 5; 866-811-4111, tinyurl.com/Life-Saki.)

title: With Falwell as Education Adviser, His Own University Could Benefit
description: On Tuesday, The Chronicle of Higher Education reported that Jerry Falwell Jr., president of Liberty University, would lead a Trump administration task force charged with deregulating American higher education.

title: Albert Brookss Modern Romance, and Other Valentines Day Massacres
description: Modern Romance, Albert Brookss 1981 comedy, isnt so modern anymore (so many phone booths!), but the humor is still startlingly deadpan, and its portrait of uncertainty about love and commitment still resonates. The film, starring and directed by Mr. Brooks, has a three-screening revisiting beginning Friday, Feb. 10, at Anthology Film Archives in the East Village as part of the annual Valentines Day Massacre, a quirky selection of movies loosely about love. Its paired with Maurice Pialats We Wont Grow Old Together, another film featuring an unstable couple. The lineup also includes two Elaine May films, The Heartbreak Kid and A New Leaf, as well as Andrzej Zulawskis Possession.

title: Retail Distractions for a Winter Weekend
description: On Thursday, Public School begins its two-month residency at the CFDA Retail Lab, a mentoring program that includes a physical store, and has filled that space with lots of tweaked prepster staples, like a long-sleeve wrinkled shirt with combo sleeves ($350) and a classic crew neck in fleece finished with a WNL embroidered patch ($350). At Cadillac House, 330 Hudson Street.

title: A Groundbreaking 20th-Century Artist, Rediscovered
description: As a young woman, Gluck (born Hannah Gluckstein) rejected her family name, along with the dress and confines of her gender.

title: Stunningly Modern Paintings by a Gender-Bending 1920s Artist
description: As a young woman, the artist Gluck rejected her family name, along with the dress and confines of her gender. With short hair and sharply cut suits, she cut a dash through the London art world of the 1920s and 30s. This week, the London gallery that mounted her first exhibition in 1926 draws together works from across Glucks career and explores her legacy in the 21st century.

title: The Uncomfortable Love Affair Between Donald Trump and the New England Patriots
description: Im not talking politics at all, Tom Brady said in response to the first of several questions about, predictably, politics. Brady has been getting a lot of these, beginning with Super Bowl weeks Opening Night on Monday at Minute Maid Park in Houston. This is not your average stick-to-sports Super Bowl week in America. The chaos in Washington, bedlam at airports and protests across the country serve as an unsettling crowd noise to even the serene superstar quarterback for the New England Patriots.

title: Listen to Evidence: March for Science Plans Washington Rally on Earth Day
description: Within a week of its creation, the March for Science campaign had attracted more than 1.3 million supporters across Facebook and Twitter, cementing itself as a voice for people who are concerned about the future of science under President Trump.

title: Matiere: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: The Modern Love Podcast: Megan Hilty Reads On the Precipice, Wings Spread
description: On this weeks podcast, the actress and singer Megan Hilty reads On the Precipice, Wings Spread, about a woman whose love overpowers her fear when she finds out her partner is H.I.V.-positive.

title: Training Day and A.P.B., Where the Rogue Cop Rules
description: Cops dont even want to make a damn traffic stop. Afraid theyll wind up on Anderson Cooper.

title: Arun Jaitley, Indias Finance Chief, Aims to Spur Economy Hit by Cash Shortage
description: NEW DELHI  Trying to spur an Indian economy hard hit by its cash shortage, the government of Prime Minister Narendra Modi unveiled plans on Wednesday for next years budget that would significantly increase spending on infrastructure, rural areas and antipoverty programs.

title: Everyone Is Welcome Here
description: This Week in Hate highlights hate crimes and harassment around the country since the election of President Trump.

title: Islanders Are on Roll, but Their Future at Barclays Center May Be in Doubt
description: Since firing Coach Jack Capuano in January, the Islanders have won five of six games, including a 3-2 victory over the first-place Washington Capitals on Tuesday. They have moved from last place in the N.H.L.s Eastern Conference to 3 points out of a playoff position.

title: Political Fashion Statements at the Mens Wear Shows
description: Of course, reality intruded. Fabulousness is no barricade against politics. Reacting to President Trumps executive order banning the entry of citizens from seven Muslim-majority nations and refugees from any country, designers who are showing their work during the four days of mens fashion in New York expressed dissent in gestures that, while mainly small and symbolic, added gravitas to the usual street-style antics and overall frivolity.

title: Healthy Payout Possible for Carlyle From Natures Bounty
description: Nutritional supplements are having a healthy effect on Carlyle. The buyout firm may be ready to part with Natures Bounty. At the $6 billion price tag reported by Bloomberg, it would deliver a substantial return for what was a pivotal deal in 2010.

title: Beyonc Is Pregnant, and Twitter Loses It
description: The reaction on social media to the news that Beyonc is pregnant with twins was by turns swift, sweet and strange.

title: Review: In Superior Donuts, Wisecracks Galore but Little Substance
description: Back in 2008, Charles Isherwood of The New York Times reviewed a new play by Tracy Letts, Superior Donuts, that was opening at the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago. The work, he wrote, could be described as a valentine to the 1970s sitcoms of Norman Lear, which featured colorfully contrasted characters, formulaic but smart comic writing and a social conscience.

title: The Menzingers Ragged Punk Peeks in the Rearview Mirror
description: Voices get hoarse. Muscles shrivel. Anger subsides. Memories fade. When a punk ages, its not always graceful. Greg Barnett, the frontman of the Menzingers, knows that all too well  We put miles on these old jean jackets, he sings  and is looking to find a dignified way through middle age.

title: The Phrase Putin Never Uses About Terrorism (and Trump Does)
description: MOSCOW  Vladimir V. Putin, Russias president, hardly misses a chance to talk tough on terrorism, once famously saying he would find Chechen terrorists sitting in the outhouse and rub them out.

title: Rings to Propose With, From $12 to $625,000
description: Diamonds arent the only options. How to show love, from plastic to rubies.

title: Rochambeau: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: Trump Era Invites a Bolder Hollywood Red Carpet
description: At last weekends round of movie and television awards, doled out by the producers and actors guilds, the likes of John Legend and Julia Louis-Dreyfus, among others, swung hard at President Trump and his travel ban, to rapturous applause. The friendly reception to hostile fire represented a departure for awards shows, where political acceptance speeches have elicited reactions from eye rolls to noisy dissent.

title: Tamron Hall Quits NBC and Today Show With Megyn Kelly Coming
description: About six months ago, Billy Bush and Tamron Hall were introduced by NBC as the new team for the 9 a.m. hour of Today.

title: Hormone Blockers Can Prolong Life if Prostate Cancer Recurs
description: Men whose prostate cancer comes back after surgery are more likely to survive if, along with the usual radiation, they also take drugs to block male hormones.

title: Review: Black Edge, an Account of a Hedge Fund Magnate and Insider Trading
description: Two men pass out in Sheelah Kolhatkars book about Wall Street skulduggery. I must confess that I was not expecting this. Hedge funders are supposed to be yodeling Tarzans, not fragile consumptives in a Verdi opera.

title: Review: Magic and Firebirds Show the Light Side of Russias Mariinsky Ballet
description: WASHINGTON  The choreographer Alexei Ratmansky, a natural storyteller, has produced more evening-length ballets in this century than most choreographers did in the 20th. Nearly all have narrative charm, vivid characterizations and marvelous designs. And most blend inventive fantasy with touching human intimacy.

title: Bella Hadid, Dianna Agron and Camille Rowe at Dior Poison Party
description: Dior celebrates a new fragrance at the Up & Down club.

title: Jury in Retrial of Etan Patzs Accused Killer Begins Deliberations
description: A second jury is now deciding the fate of a former bodega worker accused of kidnapping and killing Etan Patz  a 6-year-old boy who vanished as he walked to a school bus stop in 1979  once again raising the prospect of a resolution to a mystery that has hung over New York City for nearly four decades.

title: What You Should Watch Wednesday Night
description: Spy in the Wild: A Nature Mini-Series 8 p.m., PBS (Check Local Listings)

title: Bella Hadid, Dianna Agron and Camille Rowe at Dior Party
description: Dior celebrated its new fragrance, Poison Girl, with a party at the Manhattan hot spot Up & Down on Tuesday night. Clockwise from top left: a display inside the club; TK Wonder Quann, left, and Cipriana Quann; the scene on the dance floor; the D.J. Mia Moretti, left, and the artist Cleo Wade.

title: Open Wide: Deep-Sea Fishes That Are Built to Eat Big
description: Were about 600 to 3,000 feet below the oceans surface. Its cold, its dark and its slow down here. If youre lucky, its blue in the daytime and black at night. And the deeper we go, the darker it gets.

title: A Hip Cafe by Women, for Everybody
description: As the saying goes, Too many cooks in the kitchen spoil the broth. But not at De Maria, a stylish new restaurant on the edge of NoLIta. Even though we are all very new friends, it was very clear from the start that we all shared a common aesthetic and vision, both in design and a way of providing thoughtful dining experiences, offers De Marias culinary director and executive chef Camille Becerra. Her collaborators comprise a mostly female group of creatives and trailblazers from various industries.

title: What 9 Actors and Filmmakers Wore to the Sundance Film Festival
description: This years Sundance Film Festival, which ended on Sunday, brought together 120 feature-length films and 40 first-time filmmakers to Park City, Utah. Last Friday, as distributors shopped, producers hawked and a comedy called Fun Mom Dinner had its premiere, these six indie-film insiders showed us how they dressed for the white carpet.

title: Julio Jones, Star Falcons Receiver, Shakes Off Cornerbacks and Celebrity
description: HOUSTON  If it seems that Julio Jones does not fit the mold of a star wide receiver in the N.F.L., that may be because he did not grow up watching football. Ever. A fan of track and field and an avid watcher of the Olympics, he summed up his history of football fandom as having once watched a highlight clip of Barry Sanders.

title: Deveaux: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: New England Patriots, Rex Tillerson: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: U.S. Says Widow of Orlando Nightclub Killer Knew of Attack Plans
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  A federal prosecutor said Wednesday that Noor Salman, the widow of the man who killed 49 people at an Orlando, Fla., nightclub last June, knew that her husband was planning the assault that became one of the deadliest mass shootings in United States history.

title: RushCard Ordered to Pay $13 Million for Disruption of Prepaid Card Service
description: More than a year after a breakdown of RushCards prepaid debit card system denied thousands of customers access to their cash, a federal regulator has ordered the company and its payment processor, MasterCard, to pay $13 million in fines and restitution.

title: Judge Orders Trump-Owned Golf Resort to Pay Millions
description: In a highly unusual turn of events for a sitting president, a federal judge in Florida on Wednesday ordered a golf resort owned by President Trump to pay $5.7 million for refusing to refund deposits to members who wanted to resign from the club.

title: Trumps Black History Talk: From Douglass to Media Bias and Crime
description: In an event with black supporters billed as an African-American History Month listening session, President Trump on Wednesday veered into some of his preferred topics, including crime and media bias.

title: IBM Gives Watson a New Challenge: Your Tax Return
description: In its first steps toward commercialization, IBMs Watson took on grand, science-laden challenges like helping doctors diagnose cancer. But that is changing as IBM strives to build its artificial intelligence technology into a multibillion-dollar business.

title: Inmates Take Employees Hostage at a Delaware State Prison
description: Inmates were holding two people hostage at a Delaware prison on Wednesday night in a standoff that began in the morning and left at least one prison employee injured, officials said.

title: Bills Passed to Help Tenants of New York Three-Quarter Homes
description: Corey Bates lost his apartment when the rent was increased. His work hours were cut. So in January 2015, he jumped when a nonprofit agency referred him to a program called Back on Track that promised him temporary housing and a permanent home in six months.

title: Gentry Keeps It Fresh for Brooklyns Demanding Style Guys
description: Gentry, a boutique in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, that started in 2012 as H. W. Carter and Sons, has a good selection of workwear classics but also leads the way with trends; see the wider cropped pants as evidence. Its owner, Alan Maleh, 51, is also the founder and publisher of Man of the World, a plush quarterly magazine for style-conscious men.

title: Instant Pot Tips From Readers
description: Readers respond to Melissa Clarks story on the Instant Pot, an electric pressure cooker that is gaining in popularity.

title: Conservative Groups Unify to Push Neil Gorsuchs Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON  They are three dozen of the best-financed, most battle-hardened players in the conservative movement  among them, the Koch network, the National Rifle Association and leading evangelical and anti-abortion groups.

title: A Different Super Bowl Matchup: Politics vs. the N.F.L.
description: HOUSTON  N.F.L. officials pointed to the countrys obsession with the presidential campaign as a big reason the leagues television ratings fell during much of the regular season.

title: David Hart x Hart Schaffner Marx: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: Lennart Nilsson, Photographer Who Unveiled the Invisible, Dies at 94
description: Lennart Nilsson, an innovative Swedish photographer whose micro-cameras bared some of lifes previously impenetrable and breathtaking moments  most memorably a human embryos maturation from the instant a sperm cell fertilizes an egg  died on Saturday in Stockholm. He was 94.

title: A New Frontier in Photography
description: Lennart Nilsson fused artistic and scientific virtuosity to blaze a new frontier in photography, especially within the womb.

title: Death to Tennis: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: Bharati Mukherjee, Writer of Immigrant Life, Dies at 76
description: Bharati Mukherjee, an Indian-born American writer who explored the internal culture clashes of her immigrant characters in the award-winning collection The Middleman and Other Stories and in novels like Jasmine, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 76.

title: Looking for Parking on the Upper West Side
description: Dear Diary:

title: Staten Island Groundhog Didnt See Mayors Shadow
description: For years, the mayor of New York endured the spectacle of Groundhog Day, trekking out to the Staten Island Zoo to see if Staten Island Chuck would see its shadow.

title: Pentagon Clears Officials of Skewing Data in ISIS Reports
description: WASHINGTON  An internal Pentagon investigation found that senior officials at United States Central Command did not deliberately skew intelligence assessments about the war against the Islamic State, despite a widespread view among analysts within the command that reports were manipulated to present a distorted view of the military campaigns progress.

title: Staff Overwhelmed at Nuclear Plant, but U.S. Wont Shut It
description: PLYMOUTH, Mass.  One by one, ordinary residents confronted the federal regulators, telling them during a three-hour meeting Tuesday night that the Pilgrim Nuclear Power Station here was not safe and should be shut down.

title: Fearful of Hacking, Dutch Will Count Ballots by Hand
description: Concerned about the role hackers and false news might have played in the United States election, the Dutch government announced on Wednesday that all ballots in next months elections would be counted by hand.

title: Veterans Affairs Nominee Vows Not to Privatize Health Care
description: President Trumps pick to lead the Department of Veterans Affairs, David J. Shulkin, vowed at his Senate confirmation hearing Wednesday to reform  but not privatize  veterans health care, potentially putting him at odds with Mr. Trumps campaign promise to allow all veterans to choose private health care.

title: Anthony Scaramucci Wont Get Announced White House Role, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON  Anthony Scaramucci, an investment firm founder and a Republican donor, will not be taking a senior job at the White House as previously announced, a senior administration official said Wednesday.

title: Ollie the Bobcat Is Found Near Her Zoos Birdhouse (Where Else?)
description: She had her fun and, it appears, she was ready to come home.

title: Bornstein Letters of Health for Trump
description: Dr. Harold Bornstein wrote two letters of health for President Trump during the presidential campaign, one in December 2015 and one in September 2016.

title: Donald Trumps Longtime Doctor Says President Takes Hair-Growth Drug
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump takes medication for three ailments, including a prostate-related drug to promote hair growth, Mr. Trumps longtime physician, Dr. Harold N. Bornstein, said in a series of recent interviews.

title: Facebooks Loss in Court Doesnt Dim Excitement Over Huge Growth
description: SAN FRANCISCO  From the spread of fake news to a nasty court fight in Texas, it has been a rough few months for Facebook. But company executives can take heart in two things: Despite an audience nudging toward two billion users, more and more people are still flocking to the service, and more and more advertisers are spending money on it.

title: Todd Snyder: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: Stephen Bannon in 2014: We Are at War With Radical Islam
description: Stephen K. Bannon, the former chief of Breitbart News and now President Trumps chief strategist, was the main driver of President Trumps rapid signing on Friday of the executive order on immigration, which set off a political firestorm.

title: Trump Pushes Dark View of Islam to Center of U.S. Policy-Making
description: WASHINGTON  It was at a campaign rally in August that President Trump most fully unveiled the dark vision of an America under siege by radical Islam that is now radically reshaping the policies of the United States.

title: White House Inc.
description: As a candidate, President Trump spent contributors money for office space that he owned, stays at his resorts and food at his restaurants. He spent contributors money on Trump-branded wine and water. He displayed Trump merchandise at campaign events. Now he seems determined to milk the presidency, apparently synonymous with his brand in his eyes, for a fortune.

title: Frank Pellegrino Sr., 72, Is Dead; Proudly Rebuffed Would-Be Diners at Raos
description: Frank Pellegrino Sr., a sometime actor and the unflappable gatekeeper of Raos, his familys clannish, celebrity-studded and prohibitively exclusive restaurant in East Harlem, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Snaps Chief Taps Into the Right Now
description: LOS ANGELES  When Evan Spiegel and Bobby Murphy were undergraduates at Stanford University, they made an unconventional observation about what makes a social network valuable.

title: Herb Oscar Anderson, Crooning D.J. for WABC-AM, Dies at 88
description: Herb Oscar Anderson, the morning D.J. for the New York Top 40 station WABC-AM during most of the 1960s, died on Sunday in Bennington, Vt., near Hoosick Falls, N.Y., where he had a home. He was 88.

title: After Visa Ban, Hints of Hidden Tension on Mississippi Campus
description: STARKVILLE, Miss.  Coming from an Iranian city of around 150,000 people, Amir Rezazadeh felt a little out of place when he arrived at Mississippi State University, more than 100 miles from any metropolitan area and deep in the heart of the Bible Belt.

title: Terror Raids in Germany Reap More Doubts Than Results
description: BERLIN  Cloaked in body armor and bearing heavy weapons, more than 1,000 German police officers swooped down Wednesday on homes, offices and mosques in shock-and-awe raids centered on Germanys financial capital, Frankfurt. Nationwide, more than 50 sites were targeted.

title: Michael Phelps Enjoys Victory Lap With Jordan Spieth at Pro-Am
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  A capacity crowd of 16,000 surrounded an otherwise innocuous par-3 16th hole at TPC Scottsdale on Wednesday during the pro-am of the Phoenix Open, having gathered to watch Michael Phelps and his pro partner, the two-time major winner Jordan Spieth. The crowd was nearly the size of the one that witnessed Phelpss record eight gold medal swims at the 2008 Olympics at Beijings Water Cube, which holds 15,000.

title: Trumps Travel Ban Draws Growing Opposition From Tourism Executives
description: The travel industry responded by turns critically and cautiously to President Trumps executive order issued last week that bans travelers from seven predominantly Muslim countries from entering the United States for 90 days.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: She suddenly told me aggressively, You have to return to your country because you endanger our safety, because youre a Muslim and youre a terrorist like ISIS.

title: Protesters Vow Defiance After Miami Heeds Immigration Order
description: MIAMI  In a place that thinks of itself as the capital of Latin America, the Miami-Dade County mayors decision last week to jump out front and heed President Trumps executive order demanding cooperation with immigration agents has set off consternation and protests.

title: Raid in Yemen: Risky From the Start and Costly in the End
description: WASHINGTON  Just five days after taking office, over dinner with his newly installed secretary of defense and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, President Trump was presented with the first of what will be many life-or-death decisions: whether to approve a commando raid that risked the lives of American Special Operations forces and foreign civilians alike.

title: German Bishops Open Way to Communion for Divorced Catholics
description: Catholics in Germany who have divorced and remarried without receiving an annulment may receive communion on a case-by-case basis, the German bishops conference announced on Wednesday. The decision is a major acceleration of a more welcoming  but disputed  stance on family life adopted by the Vatican under Pope Francis.

title: Trail Activity
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Two debuts in two Thursdays! Its so nice to have some fresh faces to brighten up a humdrum, eventless January. I found this puzzle awfully clever, but I attribute solving it with few mishaps to dumb luck. One of the first crosses I made was 21D, Bygone Winter Palace resident, which had to be TSAR  and 32A, Zellweger of Chicago, which had to be RENEE. Entering them was logically impossible without learning and following this grids rule, so I knew very early on that there was a game afoot, which revealed itself when good old Ginger Spice showed up at 27D  GERI Halliwell.

title: Runner-Up Didnt Make It to Supreme Court, but He Did Get to Altoona
description: WASHINGTON  For Judge Thomas M. Hardiman, the road to the Supreme Court ended in Altoona.

title: Judge Orders U.S. to Let In Immigrant Visa Holders
description: LOS ANGELES  A federal judge has dealt another blow to President Trumps executive order barring some foreigners from coming into the United States, in a ruling that added to the confusion over the legality of the immigration measure.

title: Mexico Takes First Step Before Talks With U.S. on Nafta
description: MEXICO CITY  The Mexican government said on Wednesday that it was beginning a 90-day consultation with the countrys Senate and private sector before talks with the United States to review the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Raf Simons: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: Berkeley Cancels Milo Yiannopoulos Speech, and Donald Trump Tweets Outrage
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  A speech by the divisive right-wing writer Milo Yiannopoulos at the University of California, Berkeley, was canceled on Wednesday night after demonstrators set fires and threw objects at buildings to protest his appearance.

title: Knicks Subdue Last-Place Nets for a Needed Win
description: While the Knicks meandered through an ugly January, losing 12 of 17 games, the perception from both near and far was of a team in chaos. With a sub-.500 record and the star forward Carmelo Anthony the subject of daily trade rumors, the Knicks had done little lately to contradict that view.

title: Iran, Brexit, Romania: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: U.S.-Australia Rift Is Possible After Trump Ends Call With Prime Minister
description: WASHINGTON  A phone call between President Trump and the Australian prime minister is threatening to develop into a diplomatic rift between two stalwart allies after the two men exchanged harsh words over refugee policy, and Mr. Trump abruptly ended the call.

title: Dozens of Dakota Pipeline Protesters Are Arrested
description: The authorities in North Dakota said on Wednesday that they had arrested about 75 protesters just south of a bridge that has become a focal point of demonstrations over the Dakota Access Pipeline.

title: Whats on TV Thursday: Training Day and Powerless
description: Training Day, a series spun off from the Denzel Washington-Ethan Hawke film, catapults into a Trumpian universe. Powerless enters a DC Comics realm where the heroes dont have superpowers. And stream Amour in tribute to the French actress Emmanuelle Riva, who died on Friday.

title: Corrections: February 2, 2017
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Jim Mattis, in South Korea, Tries to Reassure an Ally
description: SEOUL, South Korea  On his first mission to reassure an important American ally, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis met on Thursday with top South Korean officials, who agreed to push ahead with the deployment of a new missile defense system.

title: Word + Quiz: obelisk
The Travel Ban and an Authoritarian Ladder of Violence
description: WASHINGTON  History is full of examples of leaders using us versus them politics to paint a particular minority group as a threat to the majoritys safety, morals or culture.

title: Super Bowl
description: Are you a football fan? Will you be watching the Super Bowl this Sunday?

title: Pences Presidential Pet
description: The world was a-swoon over Donald Trumps nomination to the Supreme Court. And the way Trump announced it.

title: Welcoming Transgender Boy Scouts
description: It took several decades of legal challenges and funding boycotts for the Boy Scouts of America to lift its ban on openly gay Scout leaders in 2015. Remarkably, organization leaders deliberated for just a few weeks before deciding to allow transgender male scouts to participate in all programs.

title: Fruit of a Poison Tree
description: So the president, who was elected under the fog of Russian interference (now under investigation by both houses of Congress) and with a boost from the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation (now under investigation by the Justice Departments inspector general), has just made a nomination to the Supreme Court: Judge Neil Gorsuch of the United States Court of Appeals for the Tenth Circuit, in Denver.

title: Trumps Mexican Shakedown
description: MEXICO CITY  In Mexicos so-called drug war, cartel gunmen have often used their violent power to demand money from innocent people. Its a heinous crime that scars communities and blights growth, and it has provoked terrorized villages to rise up to chase out the extortionists. Now Mexico finds itself facing the biggest shakedown of all from north of the Rio Grande, as the United States president demands $12 billion to $15 billion to pay for a border wall.

title: An Apology to Muslims for President Trump
description: Whenever an extremist in the Muslim world does something crazy, people demand that moderate Muslims step forward to condemn the extremism. So lets take our own advice: We Americans should now condemn our own extremist.

title: The Peculiar Populism of Donald Trump
description: All wars have unintended consequences, including culture wars.

title: Questions for: On Alaskas Coldest Days, a Village Draws Close for Warmth
description: Article: On Alaskas Coldest Days, a Village Draws Close for Warmth

title: Songs of Themselves
description: The observation that writing about music is like dancing about architecture has been attributed to everyone from Martin Mull to Frank Zappa to Thelonious Monk. Its famous enough that its almost hackneyed by now, yet its as good a description as any for the nearly impossible task of using words to describe the sacredly wordless. Get bogged down in technical terms like diatonic interval and chromatic diesis and you risk sounding gratingly wonkish. Indulge in platitudes like lyrical melody and haunting chords and youre a pathetic lightweight, a philistine.

title: Julys Book Club Pick: Pachinko, by Min Jin Lee
description: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2017. For the rest of the list, click here.)

title: McCain Steps In to Ease Tension With Australia Over Trump Insult
description: Senator John McCain steps in to assure Australia that the United States remains a stalwart ally after President Trump insulted its prime minister.

title: The Parachute Generation
description: When I first met Yang Jinkai, two days before he boarded a plane for America, the smog hanging over his industrial home city, Shenyang, had turned the sun into a ghostly orb. The 16-year-old paced around the family apartment as his mother labeled his suitcases and packed them with the comforts of home: quilted pajamas, chopsticks, instant noodles. She gestured toward a lone memento that would remain in his bedroom, a life-size needlepoint portrait of her only child, woven in shimmering gold thread. I worked on that all year, she said. I knew this moment would come.

title: Do You Think Teenagers Can Make a Difference in the World?
description: Can you think of any stories where one persons efforts influenced, inspired or improved the lives of others?

title: The Stir-Fried Tomatoes and Eggs My Chinese Mother Made
description: Over the past two years of writing this column about immigrants and their food, Ive cooked with a Filipina nurse who used scalpels to debone chicken; a Senegalese family that eats out of the same dish to emphasize everyones responsibility to one another; a Mexican Popsicle maker who tried to heal the ache of her divorce by sharing literal sweetness. There was a Slovakian pierogi master whose last act before leaving for the United States was opening the barn doors to set her animals free; a Polish vegetarian who learned to make bigos, a meatfest of a stew, just so she could share her mothers recipe; and a Palestinian family that lives the American dream by hosting a Thanksgiving every night.

title: Will You Graduate? Ask Big Data
description: At Georgia States nursing school, the faculty used to believe that students who got a poor grade in Conceptual Foundations of Nursing probably wouldnt go on to graduation. So they were surprised, after an analysis of student records stretching back a decade, to discover what really made a difference for nursing students: their performance in introductory math.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Seed Catalogs
description: The growing season never ends here in Los Angeles. Even in the depths of winter, I can read about, obsess over, order and plant new seeds all within a matter of weeks. Because thats when the seed catalogs arrive, stuffed into mailboxes around the solstice, hitting like a blast of warm air: lists of many hundreds of different fruits, vegetables and flowers. As the lengthening days start tipping toward spring, I pore over these catalogs, reading them cover to cover: There are multihued carrots and beets, cucumbers shaded yellow, orange and rust red; theres lettuce thats harvested, curiously, for its stems, and rutabagas that grow to be the size of small children. It is the closest I get in my adult life to the feeling of reading the Sharper Image catalog as a 10-year-old.

title: Trump Has Choices to Make on Climate Policy. What Would You Do?
description: Donald Trump and his cabinet have sent mixed signals on some big environmental decisions they face. Take this quiz and see where the different possible choices lead.

title: Tattoo Ink: How It Got Under New Yorks Skin
description: New Yorkers, who live in a world shaped by advertising, are suckers for self-transformation. In a choice between changing the body and changing the mind, changing the body is easier. And the easiest feature to change is skin, a blank canvas just waiting to be colored, stained or drawn on. Thats what we see happening repeatedly, imaginatively and pretty much permanently in Tattooed New York, a tightly packed survey of epidermal art opening on Friday at the New-York Historical Society.

title: Fighting Racial Bias on Campus
description: Shaun R. Harper has been at the center of the racial debate of the past year  first, as protests illuminated the concerns of students of color, then as the Trump triumph emboldened some to commit overt acts of bias, particularly against Latino and Muslim students. In his new book, Race Matters in College, due out in June from Johns Hopkins University Press, he provides a pathway for campuses struggling with these very issues. A leading scholar on racial equity in higher education, Dr. Harper will in July be leaving the University of Pennsylvania, where he founded and directed the Center for the Study of Race and Equity in Education, and joining the University of Southern California, where he will teach and start up a similar center with big ambitions. One priority is a survey to assess the racial climate on the nations campuses.

title: Fashions Latest Obsession: Chips Off the Celebrity Block
description: In Paris last week, the honor of the final exit at the Chanel couture show  the one every model wants to walk  was bestowed on a fresh-faced young women, strolling down the circular runway in a long pink dress. A coronation of sorts, it marked her as a new face of the brand, and favorite of the designer Karl Lagerfeld. Her being Lily-Rose Depp, the daughter of the actress-singer Vanessa Paradis, a former face of the brand, and Johnny Depp.

title: For Stranded Somali Refugees, Friend of America Is a Deadly Label
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Ismail Ali Ibrahim gave away everything he owned: his bed, his sheets, his shirts, his pots, his pans, his plates, even his house.

title: Where Should the President Dine in Washington? Restaurateurs Offer Tips
description: President Trump is settling into life at the White House, which is well-stocked with his favorite foods. The citys restaurateurs are curious to see if the president, who is a homebody compared with his restaurant-hopping predecessor, will show any desire to engage with a culinary scene that became vibrant during the Obama administration.

title: Supreme Court Fight Is More About Trump Than Gorsuch
description: WASHINGTON  This is a rare Supreme Court confirmation fight that will be more about the nominator than the nominee.

title: Foreigners Trapped in the United States by New Policy
description: Much of the criticism of the executive order signed by President Trump has focused on foreigners prevented from entering the country, but a court filing in the legal battle over the travel ban reveals a far broader impact, imperiling the residency status of tens of thousands of immigrants  everyone from asylum seekers to students and technology workers  already living in the United States.

title: With Trump in Town, Washington Restaurants Await a Visit (From Ivanka)
description: WASHINGTON  President George Bush liked Peking duck from a restaurant in a Virginia strip mall. President Bill Clinton liked Indian food from the Bombay Club and the occasional run to McDonalds. President Barack Obama spent eight years dining all over town, eating everything from upscale Italian at Fiola Mare to truffle macaroni and cheese at Equinox.

title: 6 Ways Girls Changed Television. Or Didnt.
description: When Girls had its premiere on HBO in 2012, it was an instant lightning rod. A dramedy about four 20-something women searching for careers and companionship in New York, it was praised for its sexually frank, wryly satirical look at millennial angst, chastised for its lack of diversity, and dissected in an endless stream of essays and social media posts thanks to its explorations of gender politics and post-collegiate social panic.

title: 36 Hours in Marrakesh
description: In Moroccos Jewel of the South, the streets and bazaars spill over with artistry, whether it be in architecture, cuisine, crafts or fine art.

title: Get Bad and Boujee Onstage With Migos
description: Hip-hop group Migos has a No. 1 hit on the Billboard chart with Bad and Boujee. Step onstage at the album release party when the crowd goes wild. (Note: Lyrics include vulgar language.)

title: Review: Robert De Niro as The Comedian, a Has-Been Seeking a Comeback
description: Is it too much to want someone to bring the funny in a movie about a comic? The enervating, would-be laugh-in The Comedian opens this week, presumably on the strength of its headliner, Robert De Niro. Hes ill-served by this movie, but hes been worse elsewhere, which isnt much of a comfort as this one drags into hour two. Like every exalted star, Mr. De Niro generates good will because of who he is and despite his ups and downs, the afterglow of his great performances enveloping him like a luminous cloud. So it takes a significantly bad movie to wipe the audiences smile off this fast.

title: The Daily: President Trumps Foreign Policy Muse
description: Back on the campaign trail, then-candidate Donald J. Trump argued that the United States faced a threat  radical Islamic terrorism  on par with fascism, Nazism and communism. He declared to a cheering crowd in Youngstown, Ohio, that those who do not believe in our Constitution or who support bigotry and hatred will not be allowed into our country.

title: Donald Trump, Australia, Betsy DeVos: Your Thursday Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: New York Today: A Groundhog Has Her Day
description: Updated, 11:28 a.m.

title: In Hawaii, a Swimmers Communion With the Wild Ocean
description: Years ago, a close friend and I cemented a friendship that began in college by splashing our way around Hawaii, on his home island, Oahu. We visited other islands, too, like Kauai, where we waded into the Pacific at Polihale Beach, a remote 17-mile stretch of white sand at the end of the long, rutted dirt road that seems as far away as you can get from anywhere.

title: Spicing Up the Colombian Melting Pot
description: Certain districts of Bogot, like the Zona G, seem to have more types of restaurants than they do people. There are Southern-style BBQ joints that look straight out of Brooklyn; gastro pubs with cocktail gardens; and a chain of crepe restaurants that has set up shop in nearly every neighborhood. Yet regional Colombian fare from outside the capital has long been the citys weak spot. Until now.

title: Three Paths to America
description: We spent all weekend trying to understand the immigration ban signed into effect by President Trump last week aimed at keeping refugees and residents of seven majority-Muslim countries from entering the United States, and realized there isnt enough bandwidth in the world to process the scale and scope of this decision.

title: Morning Agenda: Snaps I.P.O., Scaramuccis Job Withdrawn, Struggles at Deutsche Bank
description: He has been praised as a visionary with a healthy ego. He describes himself as a lucky white male. Evan Spiegel, the 26-year-old chief executive of Snap, may be all these things, but one thing is certain  he has a singular approach to business.

title: Putin Swaggers Into Hungary as Europe Wonders About U.S.
description: BUDAPEST  When President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia last paid a visit to Hungary, Prime Minister Viktor Orban was under siege for his autocratic style, Russia was isolated for its seizure of Crimea, and both men were called xenophobes for their hard-line stance on immigration.

title: Deutsche Bank Chief Apologizes for Lenders Past Misconduct
description: FRANKFURT  The chief executive of Deutsche Bank apologized in especially contrite terms on Thursday for the long list of misdeeds that tarnished the German lenders reputation and cost it billions of euros in fines and settlements, adding that bonuses of top managers would be cut.

title: When a Job Is Temporary, but the Company Doesnt Know It
description: Recently, I gave notice without having another job in place. I found that my position had become untenable and I needed to quit for my sanity and the sanity of my family.

title: Nickelodeon Wades Into Princess Politics
description: LOS ANGELES  Now its war: Nickelodeon, once again winning the childrens ratings race against Disney Channel, has decided to throw its weight behind ... a princess.

title: Northwestern Has Elusive Target in Its Sights: N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Is this finally the year for Northwestern basketball?

title: California Today: The Collapse of Organized Farm Labor
description: Good morning.

title: New York Times Co.s Decline in Print Advertising Tempered by Digital Gains
description: Precipitous declines in print advertising rocked the newspaper industry last year. And while The New York Times Company recorded significant growth in subscriptions and promising increases in digital advertising, it nevertheless has not avoided the inevitable.

title: Boston Bombing Survivor to Marry the Firefighter Who Rescued Her
description: When Roseann Sdoia was gravely injured in the Boston Marathon bombings in 2013, Michael Materia, a firefighter, was the responder who took her to the hospital. They were strangers at the time, but he has rarely left her side since.

title: Andrew Puzders Court Documents
description: Andrew Puzder's divorce records are coming under scrutiny, as an ethics group argues that abuse allegations from his former wife are relevant to his cabinet confirmation hearings because the Labor Department is charged with assuring workers physical safety.

title: Delaware Prison Standoff Ends With Correction Officer Dead
description: SMYRNA, Del.  As concern mounted about two workers held hostage inside a Delaware prison, law enforcement officers smashed a backhoe through the doors in predawn darkness on Thursday, retaking the building after an 18-hour standoff. Inside, they freed a prison counselor, but their fears were confirmed when they found a longtime corrections sergeant unresponsive.

title: On Deck With Chinas Last Junk Builders, Masters of an Ebbing Craft
description: PEARL RIVER DELTA, China  As Wong Kin-kao stands on the deck of the traditional Chinese wooden junk he is building in Shenwan, a cluster of fish ponds and factories in the Pearl River Delta of southern China, he shouts to be heard over the shriek of metalwork from steel ships that are being worked on nearby.

title: Curing Partisanship
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: At Kansas, Recent Off-Court Troubles Threaten to Scar a Grand History
description: LAWRENCE, Kan.  All the gooey things a Kansas Jayhawks basketball fan is liable to tell you about his team feel true on a winter night in Allen Fieldhouse. This is the case even at a time when serious off-the-court concerns threaten to impugn one of the better reputations in major college basketball. And it is never more the case than when the Jayhawks enter a game as the third-ranked team in the country  and facing a conference rival ranked even higher.

title: Brazen Killing of Myanmar Lawyer Came After He Sparred With Military
description: YANGON, Myanmar  The soft-spoken rights lawyer had devised a plan to replace Myanmars Constitution with one that would strip the military of its extraordinary political powers.

title: Case Study in Chaos: How Management Experts Grade a Trump White House
description: For someone who promoted his management skills and campaigned as an organizational genius, as Anderson Cooper of CNN put it, it has been a rocky White House debut for Donald J. Trump, the first president to go directly from the executive suite to the Oval Office.

title: Matthew McConaughey Lectures Hollywood on Trump, and Breitbart Pounces
description: Amid the din of celebrities speaking out against President Trump, add one conciliatory voice: That of Matthew McConaughey, who said in a televised BBC interview that Hollywood should embrace Mr. Trumps election and work with him.

title: Trump Vows to Destroy Law Banning Political Endorsements by Churches
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump vowed on Thursday to overturn a law restricting political speech by tax-exempt churches, a potentially huge victory for the religious right and a gesture to evangelicals, a voting bloc he attracted to his campaign by promising to free up their pulpits.

title: 94 Psychiatric Patients in South Africa Died of Negligence, Report Finds
description: Corpses of psychiatric patients were found with head injuries and unexplained bruises. Relatives were not informed of the deaths of their loved ones. The transfers of mentally ill patients were seen as business opportunities.

title: A Couple Used to Breaking the Color Line
description: Jewelle Taylor and James Gibbs Jr. were among the earliest African-American couples to appear in the modern wedding announcements.

title: Even as Hate Moves Online, K.K.K. Fliers Show Up on Maine Lawns in Dead of Night
description: Robert Gregoire, the police chief of Augusta, Me., was sipping coffee at home on Monday morning when a neighbor knocked on his door to report something disturbing.

title: Copy Edit This! Quiz No. 3
description: The Timess standards editor, Philip B. Corbett, invites readers to correct grammatical errors in recent New York Times articles.

title: The Police Killed My Unarmed Son in 2012. Im Still Waiting for Justice.
description: Five years ago today, my unarmed 18-year-old son, Ramarley Graham, was unjustly killed when police officers burst into our home in the Bronx and shot him in front of his grandmother and 6-year-old brother.

title: Illustrated Interview | Marge Simpson
description: The supermom with the blue bouffant, who stars in the animated sitcom "The Simpsons," currently in its 28th season on Fox, sketched her answers on a quiet day in Springfield in between cooking, cleaning and burping the baby.

title: The Johnson Amendment, Which Trump Vows to Destroy, Explained
description: WASHINGTON  When President Trump told an audience of religious leaders on Thursday that he would destroy the Johnson Amendment, he declared his intention to sign a bill that would fundamentally alter a major aspect of the church-state divide that has been a constant in American politics for generations.

title: The Best Places to Walk in Paris
description: In her new book, Flneuse, Lauren Elkin expands the concept of the flneur  that aristocratic bohemian man strolling the city streets, possibly with a top hat or some other touch of the dandy  to include women wanderers from Virginia Woolf to Sophie Calle (one of whose works will be featured in Person of the Crowd: The Contemporary Art of Flnerie, soon to open at the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia). Elkin also retraces her own steps in life, and, here, shares five places in her adopted home of Paris that she finds herself returning to again and again.

title: For the Love of Italy
description: Take a 91-year-old Tuscan country chef, add the revered architect Renzo Mongiardino, and mix with the designs of Studio Peregalli  and you have some of the most exquisite restaurants in Milan, if not the world.

title: Scott Pruitt, Trumps E.P.A. Pick, Is Approved by Senate Committee
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans pressed forward on Thursday with the confirmation of President Trumps nominee to head the Environmental Protection Agency, Scott Pruitt, suspending the Environment and Public Works Committees rules to approve the cabinet pick despite a Democratic boycott.

title: Challenge for Super Bowl Commercials: Not Taking Sides, Politically
description: The Super Bowl is a popular destination for commercials showcasing premium water, candy and beer  but politics can make it a difficult forum.

title: Video Review: Nissan Sentra Nismo Offers Affordable Spunk, but Underwhelms
description: You know what FOMO is, right? As defined by the Oxford English Dictionary  yes, it is in that dictionary  it is the Fear of Missing Out, angst that something exciting is happening and you are excluded. In other words, it is my social life.

title: Shopping for Chardonnay With the Queen of Wine-Soaked Cabaret
description: Bridget Everetts cabaret show is known to have a splash zone. The 44-year-old queen of no-holds-barred music and comedy often bites the cork out of a bottle of chardonnay and spits it at the audience before indulging and then liberally spraying the crowd. (She is also known to end each performance by sitting on an audience members face.) So it came as no surprise that, as I joined her on a recent shopping trip, the first thing she said was, I start right at California Chardonnays  shall we go?

title: Delivering Lunch in Mumbai, Across Generations
description: Kiran Gavande, 32, is a supervisor for the Mumbai Dabbawala Association.

title: Searching for a Fixer-Upper
description: Karen Asprea grew up in Bensonhurst and Marine Park, Brooklyn, and studied interior design at Pratt Institute. She moved briefly to Murray Hill in Manhattan, but a little over a year ago, she returned to Brooklyn. There, she rented a one-bedroom in Park Slope for $2,350 a month, primarily as a base for hunting for a place to buy.

title: Schwarzenegger to Trump: Why Dont We Switch Jobs?
description: President Trump and Arnold Schwarzenegger were embroiled in a long-distance feud on Thursday after the president used a prayer breakfast speech to taunt the action star about his reality show ratings, and Mr. Schwarzenegger fired back in a video posted on Twitter.

title: Harvard Student: I Worry If I Leave, I Wont Be Let Back In
description: I am one of thousands potentially affected by Fridays executive order, which promises to be a great disservice not only to immigrants, but also to America.

title: How Trump Could Protect Workers Rights
description: President Trump has found something worth saving from the Obama era. According to a statement issued this week by the White House, Mr. Trump will retain an executive order from 2014 that bars discrimination against LGBTQ people at companies that do business with the federal government.

title: Nashville Officer Is Found Dead After Attempting to Save a Suicidal Woman
description: A Tennessee police officer was found dead on Thursday morning after he was swept into the Cumberland River while attempting to save a suicidal woman, the Metropolitan Nashville Police Department said.

title: An Early Trump Backer Awaits His Reward
description: Before he bet big on Donald J. Trump last spring, Duke Buchan III was a mostly anonymous figure on Wall Street.

title: Daily Report: Peter Thiel and the Love of Several Countries
description: For such an influential venture capitalist, Peter Thiel managed to stay under the radar for a long time.

title: Animal Rights Group Says Video Shows Abuse of Sheep
description: Lamb inhabits a sleepy corner of the meat business in America, with far fewer sales than chicken, beef or pork and often raised by small producers. It is popular, however, among growing demographic groups like Latinos and Muslims, and some consumers who eat lamb because they believe the animals are raised more humanely, far from feedlots and the practices of large-scale meat production.

title: What if Ghosting an Old Friend Doesnt Work?
description: Many years ago, I was friends with a guy. There was no acrimonious breakup; we simply drifted apart. But he is needy, so I consciously ignored his attempts to get in touch over the years. Lately, he has renewed his efforts to reach me. I send his calls straight to voice mail. But that doesnt stop him from trying several times in a row or leaving long (occasionally mean) messages. He is clearly living in the past and not taking the hint that I dont want to speak with him. How do I get rid of him without changing my number?

title: Solving the Case of the Macs Disappearing Scroll Bars
description: Q. I recently switched to a Mac laptop, and the Safari browser confuses me. Sometimes it has scroll bars on the side of the page, and sometimes it doesnt. Why is this?

title: Trumps Harsh Talk With Malcolm Turnbull of Australia Strains Another Alliance
description: BEIJING  President Trumps combative phone call with Australias prime minister over a refugee agreement has set off a political storm in that country, one that threatens to weaken support for a seven-decade alliance with the United States just as many Australians say they want closer ties with China.

title: Review: In 24: Legacy, Jack Bauers Gone. The Demons Are the Same.
description: Until the Trump presidency became a reality, the main order of business in any review of 24: Legacy would have been to assess whether the franchise is still viable without Jack Bauer, Kiefer Sutherlands memorable counterterrorism operative, as its lead character. Now, though, and especially given the events of the past week, its the shows chosen villains, not its hero, who demand attention.

title: Bang on a Can Marathon Moves to Brooklyn Museum
description: The Bang on a Can Marathon will celebrate its 30th anniversary in a new home across the East River. After many years in downtown Manhattan, the annual eight-hour celebration of contemporary classical music will take place at the Brooklyn Museum on Saturday, May 6.

title: G.O.P. Campaign to Repeal Obamacare Stalls on the Details
description: WASHINGTON  Congresss rush to dismantle the Affordable Care Act, once seemingly unstoppable, is flagging badly as Republicans struggle to come up with a replacement and a key senator has declared that the effort is more a repair job than a demolition.

title: The Life of a Refugee Questioned by Trump
description: President Trump has questioned a deal to bring migrants held by Australia into the United States as refugees. Here is what daily life looks like for one of them.

title: Review: I Am Not Your Negro Will Make You Rethink Race
description: A few weeks ago, in reaction to something we had written about blackness and whiteness in recent movies, my colleague Manohla Dargis and I received a note from a reader. Since when is everything about race? he wanted to know. Perhaps it was a rhetorical question.

title: 1933 | The President Assumes Dictatorial Powers. Quickly.
description: Times Insider shares historical insights from The New York Times.

title: What Are Critics Saying About Drew Barrymores Netflix Zombie Comedy, Santa Clarita Diet?
description: An early teaser for Netflixs new horror comedy Santa Clarita Diet took the form of a commercial for a weight-loss program. Although details about the show were scant at the time, a shot of its bubbly star, Drew Barrymore, savoring a morsel of raw, human flesh was the first hint that shed be playing a suburban California mom who also happens to be a zombie.

title: How to Cook for a Dinner Party Without Ignoring Your Guests
description: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? My job is to answer them. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

title: Chocolate Sculpture, With a Bitter Taste of Colonialism
description: Until this week, Mathieu Kilapi Kasiama, an illiterate palm-nut cutter and sculptor from an impoverished region in the Democratic Republic of Congo, had never left the area, let alone flown in an airplane. And until recently, Mr. Kasiama had never tasted chocolate, the medium for his sculpture, made from the cacao beans that were a prime export during Belgiums brutal rule of Congo and the countrys exploitation by Western companies.

title: Protests Rock Romania After Government Weakens Corruption Law
description: Huge protests, among the largest since the fall of communism, have rocked Romania after the government passed a law that would effectively allow official corruption.

title: 5 Must-See Shows in New York This Month
description: No matter what T. S. Eliot said, February is if not the cruelest month, certainly the bleakest. Which makes the bright blaze of new theater offerings in New York all the more welcome. Those setting fire to stages in Manhattan and Brooklyn include a divinely demented silent screen star, a pointillist painter, a saint at the stake and, oh yes, Everybody.

title: Trump Embraces Pillars of Obamas Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, after promising a radical break with the foreign policy of Barack Obama, is embracing some key pillars of the former administrations strategy, including warning Israel to curb settlement construction, demanding that Russia withdraw from Crimea and threatening Iran with sanctions for ballistic missile tests.

title: The Hudson Theater Is Back on Broadway
description: One of Broadways oldest surviving theaters is now its youngest.

title: Should Dollar Rise or Fall? The Trump Teams Message Is Garbled
description: For a very long time, if you asked United States government officials their view on the value of the dollar, they would almost certainly decline to answer. The currency is the purview of the Treasury secretary, theyd say.

title: Dogs on Marijuana: Not Cool
description: Something was wrong with Betsy Gotbaums poodle.

title: Visa Ban Amended to Allow Iraqi Interpreters Into U.S.
description: BAGHDAD  The Trump administration amended its visa ban on Thursday to allow emigration by the families of Iraqi interpreters who served the United States government and military forces deployed in their country.

title: Jim Mattis, Romania, Rodrigo Duterte: Your Morning Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: In the Pocket: How Tom Brady and Matt Ryan Pass Under Pressure
description: Matt Ryan and Tom Brady are the prototypical pocket passers. But Brady was better protected this season and Ryan was a little better under pressure.

title: In Your Face on Smoking
description: To the Editor:

title: Iran, Puzzled by Trump, Treads Carefully for Now
description: TEHRAN  Until two weeks ago, Irans clerics felt comfortable leading worshipers in a chorus of Death to America while simultaneously signing a $16.6 billion deal with Boeing. Now, that status quo seems very long ago and the establishment is treading carefully, with even most hard-liners concerned that the smallest provocation could lead to military conflict.

title: The Purpose of Sleep? To Forget, Scientists Say
description: Over the years, scientists have come up with a lot of ideas about why we sleep.

title: Dodd-Franks Bankruptcy Provision Could Be a Trump Target
description: This week, President Trump, in signing another in a seemingly endless parade of executive orders, vowed to do a big number on Dodd-Frank, the 2010 law enacted in response to the financial crisis.

title: The Boy Scouts Inclusiveness
description: To the Editor:

title: Jared Kushners Silence on Muslim Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Lady Gaga Coy on Details of Super Bowl Halftime Show
description: HOUSTON  In the lead-up to Super Bowl LI on Sunday, politics has permeated the N.F.L.s shield to an unusual degree, with players, owners and even the leagues commissioner being asked about President Trump and his recent policy decisions.

title: Amid Opioid Overdoses, Ohio Coroners Office Runs Out of Room for Bodies
description: The bodies just keep arriving. On Thursday, only two days into February, the coroners office in Dayton, Ohio, had already handled 25 deaths  18 caused by drug overdoses. In January, the office processed 145 cases in which the victims bodies had been destroyed by opioids.

title: Trump Rude Toward Australia
description: To the Editor:

title: Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About Manufacturing Wine
description: SACRAMENTO  Its been said that all one needs to make wine is contained in the grapes themselves. But anyone who believes that must never have visited the Unified Wine & Grape Symposium, an annual trade fair for the industry, which was held here in late January at the Sacramento Convention Center.

title: Standing Up to President Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Mens Fashion Show: Raf Simons
description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2017 collection that was presented in New York on Wednesday.

title: For Europe, Theres a New Threat in Town: The U.S.
