description: LONDON  The European Union is accustomed to crises. But it is probably safe to say that none of the 28 leaders who are gathering in Malta on Friday expected the crisis that has overtaken the agenda: the United States of America.

title: Oscars 2017: Where to Stream the Nominated Movies
description: Several Oscar-nominated films are still in theaters. Heres where you can stream the rest.

title: The Gumbo Bros
description: Cajun gumbo and authentic po boys from two sons of the Gulf Coast.

title: Cajun, Far From Home, at the Gumbo Bros
description: Adam Lathan, the chef of the Gumbo Bros, lays no claim to the one true gumbo. I cant make it like your grandmother did, he said apologetically. Ill try my best.

title: Santiago Calatrava to Design His First London Complex
description: LONDON  The Spanish-born architect Santiago Calatrava is known among New Yorkers as the designer of the World Trade Center Transportation Hub, which cost almost twice its original $2.2 billion estimate, an overshoot that has been attributed partly to him.

title: A Pounder of a Cocktail at the Reinvented Chumleys
description: Chumleys is one of those New York City landmarks with so much history its hard to know where to begin in telling it. The West Village bar was a Depression-era speakeasy; a rough-and-tumble watering hole for generations of writers, including Ernest Hemingway, Jack Kerouac and Norman Mailer; a divey hangout for N.Y.U. kids; and a bar tended and patronized by the firefighters of Ladder 5.

title: Paris Turns to Flower-Growing Toilet to Fight Public Urination
description: In cities the world over, men (and, to a lesser extent, women) who urinate in the street  al fresco  are a scourge of urban life, costing millions of dollars for cleaning and the repair of damage to public infrastructure. And, oh, the stench.

title: The Guggenheim Museums Deputy Director Steps Down
description: Ari Wiseman, the deputy director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation since 2010, is stepping down to start an independent design studio in Los Angeles with one of his brothers, the artist and designer David Wiseman.

title: Deal Advisers Face a Tricky Period for M.&A.
description: Independent advisory shops face a tricky 2017. Evercore, Greenhill and Lazard, which reported estimates-beating earnings on Thursday, proved their resilience last year by weathering a choppy environment better than most big bank rivals. Continued success, though, requires confident clients. And they are looking for President Trump and Congress to ensure that happens.

title: From a Sedan to a Drop Top
description: Customizing companies are filling the desires of people who want their cars to be convertibles.

title: With a Saw and a Big Budget, Owners Transform Cars Into Convertibles
description: A few days ago, Jeff Moran fired up an electric Sawzall cutting tool and sheared off the roof of a new Dodge Challenger sedan. Next week hes going to decapitate another car, probably a Cadillac ATS.

title: Protests Force Speech Cancellation
description: Protests at the University of California, Berkeley, forced the cancellation of a speech by the right-wing writer Milo Yiannopoulos on Wednesday. He responded with his own video posted to YouTube later that night, saying that the left had become antithetical to free speech. President Trump also weighed in with a tweet.

title: Yemenis Close Bodegas and Rally to Protest Trumps Ban
description: Thousands of Yemeni-Americans and their supporters rallied in Brooklyn on Thursday to denounce President Trumps executive order on immigration, hours after hundreds of Yemeni-owned bodegas and grocery stores around New York closed to protest the order.

title: How Trump Would Corrupt the Pulpit
description: President Trump just reiterated his campaign promise to get rid of and totally destroy the law prohibiting churches and other nonprofit tax-exempt institutions from endorsing political candidates.

title: tienne Tshisekedi, Congo Opposition Leader for Decades, Dies at 84
description: tienne Tshisekedi, a cunning and relentless Congolese opposition leader who was a thorn in the side of his countrys big men for decades, died on Wednesday in Brussels. He was 84.

title: Refugees Annotate Trumps Executive Order
description: Shock, confusion and despair in response to the president's decision.

title: Angelina Jolie: Refugee Policy Should Be Based on Facts, Not Fear
description: Refugees are men, women and children caught in the fury of war, or the cross hairs of persecution. Far from being terrorists, they are often the victims of terrorism themselves.

title: Republicans Move to Block Rule on Coal Mining Near Streams
description: Republicans on Thursday took one of their first steps to officially dismantle Obama-era environmental regulations by easing restrictions on coal mining, bolstering an industry that President Trump has made a symbol of Americas neglected heartland.

title: Stampd: Mens Collection
description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: On Bernard Lumpkins Wall, a Visual Conversation About His Roots
description: When his father was ailing, Bernard Lumpkin felt a new urgency to understand the elder mans experience as an African-American who grew up in the Watts neighborhood in South Los Angeles before moving to New York to become a physicist.

title: Images of Nature  Taken Indoors
description: Federico Ciameis Travel Without Moving series features photos taken in the digital archives of historical explorers, and in a museum of natural history.

title: Soccer Ball Heading May Cause Concussion Symptoms
description: Soccer players who frequently head the ball may be increasing their risk for concussion, a new study reports.

title: Ken Fulks Lofty Perch
description: The designer counts Silicon Valley titans among his clients, and his own house is striking as well.

title: A Tour of Ken Fulks Midcentury House in San Francisco
description: Age 51

title: The Rehabilitation of Pitbull, a Former Wrestler and Neo-Nazi
description: Duke Schneider is an aging professional wrestler known as Pitbull and a retired Rikers Island guard. And for eight years, he was a member of the National Socialist Movement. His devotion was first to Adolf Hitler and second to the cadre of neo-Nazis he commanded from his Brooklyn home.

title: Riccardo Tisci Leaves Givenchy: What It Means
description: Yet another seismic shift is taking place in French fashion. Riccardo Tisci, the creative director of Givenchy and the designer responsible for redefining the brand Audrey Hepburn built for the Kardashian era, said on Thursday that he was leaving the brand after 12 years. A successor has not been announced.

title: After Outcry, Murder Charge Filed in Death of Former N.F.L. Player Joe McKnight
description: A grand jury indicted Ronald Gasser Jr. on Thursday in the fatal  shooting of the former N.F.L. player Joe McKnight, handing down a second-degree murder charge. The charge is more severe than the one that Mr. Gasser had initially faced in December, when critics complained that racial bias may have affected the investigation.

title: 10 Things to Know About Riccardo Tiscis Reign at Givenchy
description: On Thursday it was announced that Riccardo Tisci would leave Givenchy after 12 years at the house. (The brand will not show its spring/summer 2017 collection in Paris on March 5 as planned.) Here, T rounds up 10 highlights from his time at the helm.

title: Alfred Sisley: The Unheralded Impressionist
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  A reforming spirit swept through art history in the 1970s, when an academic discipline that once prized close looking above all else began to think about matters beyond form and symbolism. To truly see French painting of the late 19th century, historians averred, you had to understand their social history too  the urban reconstruction witnessed by the bourgeois Parisians in a painting by Gustave Caillebotte, or the health laws that regulated Henri de Toulouse-Lautrecs prostitutes, or the class divisions expressed by the clothes of Georges Seurats Sunday parkgoers.

title: Uber C.E.O. to Leave Trump Advisory Council After Criticism
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Travis Kalanick needed everyone to take a deep breath.

title: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
description: Through Feb. 18. Bortolami, 520 West 20th Street, Manhattan; 212-727-2050, bortolamigallery.com.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | Lion
description: Garth Davis narrates a sequence from his film featuring Sunny Pawar.

title: Whats New in NYC Theater
description: Our guide to plays and musicals coming to New York stages  and a last-chance pick of a show that is about to close. Our reviews of open shows are at nytimes.com/reviews/theater.

title: Garth Davis Reveals the Secret to Child Performances in Lion
description: What is the best way to direct the performance of a little boy lost? The filmmaker Garth Davis tried a few disorienting techniques with his actor Sunny Pawar in this scene from the movie Lion, which was nominated for six Academy Awards.

title: Comedy in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to stand-up, improv and variety shows.

title: Riccardo Tiscis Givenchy
description: Looks from the designer Riccardo Tisci of Givenchy.

title: Snaps Filing for I.P.O.
description: In its first public prospectus, Snapchats parent is trying to show how durable its business is. Snap is expected to seek a market valuation of more than $20 billion from investors.

title: Film Series in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to film series and special screenings. All our movie reviews are at nytimes.com/reviews/movies.

title: In A&E, Womens Soccer League Gets an Investor and a Bigger Platform
description: The five-year-old National Womens Soccer League has sold an equity stake to A&E Television Networks as part of a broad sponsorship and broadcast-rights agreement that will provide the league with an infusion of cash, steady national television exposure and something it may value even more: an investor committed to its future.

title: Republicans Try a New Tack on Climate Change
description: Not long ago, many Republican officeholders had a simple answer when asked about the changing climate: What changing climate?

title: New Faces (and Bodies) in Classic Roles at New York City Ballet
description: No performing art is more dependent on  more differentiated by  the individual contributions of its interpreters than ballet. If you dont feel this arts spell, try seeing any important classical work with two or more different casts in a top-level company. At New York City Ballet (more than with any other troupe), a constant element is the promotion of young talent to leading roles. Not so infrequently, you can see a junior dancer from the corps de ballet and a senior ballerina tackle the same star role on consecutive days.

title: What About the Trump Presidency Surprises a Reporter Who Has Covered Him From the Start?
description: For those who spent months and months carefully watching the Trump candidacy, campaign, and postelection activities, what, if anything, is surprising about his first days as President? We asked the Times reporter Jonathan Martin, who began covering then candidate Trump in the spring of 2015.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: No matter how much free time you have this weekend, we have TV recommendations for you. Come back every Friday for new suggestions from our TV critic on what to watch.

title: Arguing for a Judge Today, and Before Him Tomorrow
description: Neal K. Katyal was for a time the top lawyer in the Obama administration. As acting solicitor general, he represented the government before the Supreme Court. He is no conservative, and says he is disappointed that the latest nominee to the court is from the White House of President Trump.

title: Trial Documents Show Dylann Roof Had Mental Disorders
description: Acting as his own lawyer, Dylann S. Roof, the young white supremacist convicted of killing nine African-American worshipers at a church in Charleston, S.C., stood before a federal jury last month and insisted that theres nothing wrong with me psychologically. But documents unsealed this week reveal that less than two months earlier a court-appointed psychiatrist had found him to have a host of disorders and that several months before the June 2015 massacre Mr. Roof had described himself as deeply depressed.

title: Review of Trumps Immigration Order by Office of Legal Counsel
description: The Office of Legal Counsel, part of the Justice Dept., released a memorandum on Thursday, after it was requested by The New York Times through the Freedom of Information Act, reviewing President Trump's executive order called, Protecting the Nation From Foreign Terrorist Entry Into the United States.

title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

title: Women Rule Halftime. Can Lady Gaga Make It Rock Again?
description: Where did all the rocker guys go? In recent years, women have almost completely taken over the most highly visible gig in American pop: the Super Bowl halftime show, 12 minutes of music beamed worldwide. It is a ratings magnet, a marketing tool, a sponsors flagship, a cultural event and, of course, a live performance with no second chances, to be applauded or ruthlessly dissected, virtually in real time, via every internet resource.

title: A Japanese Crime Thriller in Which Crime Is the Least of It
description: ISESAKI, Japan  Hideo Yokoyama is one of Japans most popular crime novelists. Yet he regards the crime as the least interesting part of the stories he tells.

title: Netflixs The OA and the Transformative Power of Dance
description: A young woman, blind and adopted, disappears from a small town. When she returns seven years later, she can see. But thats not the strangest part about The OA, a brooding Netflix series that involves abductions, brain experiments and a shooting. The real surprise is the choreography.

title: Snapchat Parent Showcases Its Strength in Preparation for I.P.O.
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Snapchat may have been built on disappearing messages. But as the social media darling hovers on the cusp of becoming a public company, its parent is trying to show how durable its business is.

title: Philippe Jordan, a Conductor Who Excels at Juggling Jobs
description: PARIS  It was 10:45 on a gray, chilly January morning here. The conductor Philippe Jordan was spending a rehearsal break on a couch in his spacious office at the Bastille Opera House, looking through the score of Mozarts Cos Fan Tutte. He had already spent an hour with the Paris Operas orchestra going over Cos, which was two weeks away from opening in a new production directed by the Belgian choreographer Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker.

title: Review: Youth in Oregon Takes a Family on a Contentious Ride
description: The only person involved in the making of Youth in Oregon  a gratingly awful family drama about assisted suicide  who seems to grasp the movies thematic potential is its cinematographer, Ross Riege. His warmly lighted, softly smudged images convey a world becoming slowly less distinct, as if being viewed through increasingly distanced eyes.

title: Review: Santa Clarita Diet, a Suburban Sitcom With Bite
description: Santa Clarita Diet on Netflix (10 episodes available on Friday) is an odd and yet oddly simple series. Think of it as Ozzie and Harriet and Zombies.

title: Jaroslav Halak, Odd Man Out With Islanders, Settles Into Life in Minors
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  Wearing a home blue and orange jersey with his familiar No. 41, Jaroslav Halak made save after save in his most recent game, then was mobbed by happy teammates after his fifth straight victory.

title: Review: War on Everyone Is Missing Some Crucial Components
description: Squealing tires, firing guns, free-floating nihilism and an occasional look-at-me name check (Simone de Beauvoir) are all part of the package in War on Everyone. A compendium of strained talk and post-Tarantino clichs, this is a deeply disappointing new picture by the writer and director John Michael McDonagh, whose first two movies  The Guard and Calvary  popped with bright colors, splenetic jokes and actual ideas about people and the world. Mr. McDonaghs palette and spleen remain mostly intact, but here hes neglected to include a story or point.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Who Is Edward Snowden?

title: Pointing to Trump, Groups Reject U.S. Aid to Fight Extremism
description: WASHINGTON  Community groups in Michigan and Minnesota have decided to reject hundreds of thousands of dollars in federal aid to fight violent extremism because of what they call the Trump administrations vilification of Muslims.

title: Review: The Space Between Us, the Story of a Boy Who Fell to Earth
description: With the disappearance of video stores, there is something heartening about the existence of The Space Between Us, a cheesy hunk of science fiction from Peter Chelsom that once would have drawn curious young eyes to VHS shelves. Set in the near future, it plays like a transmission from 1986, when a boy and a spaceships robot pilot could raise hell in Flight of the Navigator, and Steven Spielberg set the blockbuster template to emulate.

title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to the citys best classical music and opera.

title: This Weeks Movies: Feb. 2, 2017
description: The New York Times film critics review The Space Between Us, The Comedian and I Am Not Your Negro."

title: Trump Looks to Another Finance Veteran for Senior Role
description: The founder of Cerberus Capital Management, an investment firm that owns companies like the gun maker Remington Outdoor and the supermarket chain Albertsons, is in discussions to join the Trump administration, the firm disclosed on Thursday.

title: 7 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Feel like getting away? Go ahead and dive into Arthur Conan Doyles London, explore the world of women in early Mormonism or journey across the Rocky Mountains to get a sense of how Americas geography has shaped its role in the world. Not far enough afield? A debut novel toggles between Russia and the U.S. across three generations, a South African novelist remembers her sisters life (and death) in Johannesburg and a collection of poetic short stories is largely set in Louisiana.

title: Dance in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to dance performances.

title: Review: Oklahoma City Recalls a Chilling Attack With Lessons for Today
description: Because the documentary Oklahoma City is an episode of American Experience, opening theatrically before airing on PBS on Tuesday, and because it documents events that were widely broadcast on television, much of the movie plays like a tightly edited rundown of familiar material.

title: New England Patriots, Lady Gaga: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Growing Up Smith Plants a Boy From India in 1979 America
description: The nostalgic haze that used to be associated with the 1950s seems to have drifted forward in time in recent years, with the latest example being Growing Up Smith, a gentle cross-cultural film about a 10-year-old boy from India who is navigating childhood with his immigrant family in a generic American suburb in 1979.

title: Art and Museums in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to new art shows  and some that will be closing soon.

title: Long-Ago Brooklyn Brewer Left Hidden Vaults, and Mystery
description: The only thing on tap these days at 33 Ten Eyck Street in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is memories. The beer has been gone so long that it took an archaeologist to figure out that four underground caverns were once a brewers vaults.

title: United States to Australia: Get Lost
description: Lets imagine for a moment Rex Tillerson, the newly installed secretary of state, awakening to this tweet from President Trump about an important American ally:

title: What Snaps I.P.O. Filing Reveals About the Company
description: Snap, the parent of Snapchat, disclosed several important aspects of its business in its initial public offering document. The complete filing is here. Below are notable excerpts.

title: Review: In A Good American, Examining Sept. 11 and Data Collection
description: A Good American opens with the voice of a woman calling from a hijacked plane on Sept. 11. The documentary then moves to an explosive assertion: It says that ThinThread, a data collection program, absolutely would have prevented 9/11. Thats according to William E. Binney, a former technical director at the National Security Agency and the principal subject of this film.

title: Preterm Birth May Be Early Warning of Heart Disease in Women
description: A preterm birth appears to be an early warning signal of a womans risk for heart disease, a new study shows.

title: Events for Children in NYC This Week
description: Our guide to cultural events in New York City for families with children and teenagers.

title: Review: Eloise Has the Usual Haunted-Hospital Clichs
description: Life is tough for skilled if unremarkable actresses like Eliza Dushku, who, despite early success, can be left foraging among fair-to-middling television series and forgettable movies. Even so, her career dips to a new low with Eloise, a horror movie of such ineptitude that it invites sympathy for even its least gifted participants.

title: Review: In Dark Night, Another Movie Theater, Another Shooting
description: Dark Night, written and directed by Tim Sutton, is a movie about a massacre at a movie theater. It was inspired by, and explicitly refers to, the fatal shootings committed by James Holmes at an Aurora, Colo., showing of the film The Dark Knight Rises. The wordplay of the title is sufficiently egregious that a potential viewer is apt to think, Well, if it got a distributor, it has to be better than that. It is not.

title: Review: Chapter & Verse Tells of Prison and Redemption
description: From the way the scene is framed, viewers can tell the beginning of this powerful movie is in fact its tragic-seeming end. On a rainy night in Harlem, a muscular man sits on a milk cart, smoking a cigarette, waiting. What hes waiting for, a police car, is not long in coming. In voice-over, the man introduces himself as L, adding: Check with your crew. Find out who I am.

title: Review: This Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous, a Self-Made Cover Girl
description: Gigi Lazzarato is very much a self-generated celebrity of the 21st-century vintage. That sounds like a possibly bad thing, and one of the achievements of This Is Everything: Gigi Gorgeous is its very entertaining demonstration that its not  at least not necessarily.

title: Review: Sophie and the Rising Sun Has Forbidden Love in a Foreboding Time
description: The veneer of decorum that cloaks the fictional fishing village of Salty Creek, S.C., does little to smother the stink of prejudice in Sophie and the Rising Sun, a genteel love story set in the autumn of 1941 during the run-up to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor.

title: Streaming Lava, Collapsing Cliffs and a Hawaii Volcanos Spectacular Show
description: Off the coast of the island of Hawaii, hundreds of millions of gallons of lava are flowing into the ocean like blood from a ruptured artery. Starting in January at Klauea Volcanos Kamokuna ocean entry, the lava hit the salty water, shooting molten rock upward and outward, accompanied by a rising, steamy cloud of acid.

title: Harold Rosen, Who Ushered in the Era of Communication Satellites, Dies at 90
description: Whether you are reading these words online or in print, there is a strong chance that Harold A. Rosen played a part in getting them to you. Mr. Rosen, who died on Monday at 90 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif., was a driving force in the invention of modern communication satellite technology.

title: Trump Takes the Hair-Growth Drug Propecia. How Does It Work?
description: The revelation by his longtime doctor that President Trump takes a medication to prevent hair loss has piqued curiosity about the drug.

title: Justice Dept. Reverses Policy That Sped Up Deportations
description: The Justice Department this week rescinded the Obama administrations policy of speeding up hearings and deportations of families and children seeking refuge in the United States, a move applauded by immigration advocates who had called the practice unfair and ineffective.

title: Gina Haspel, C.I.A. Deputy Director, Had Role in Torture
description: Updated March 13, 2018: President Trump announced that he had ousted Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson and intended to replace him with Mike Pompeo, now the C.I.A. director.

description: The label shows their fall 2017 designs.

title: Harry Mathews, Idiosyncratic Writer, Dies at 86
description: Half of Harry Mathewss novel The Sinking of the Odradek Stadium was written in unintelligible pidgin English, which may explain why 25 publishers rejected it.

title: 9 Syrian Officials Are Accused of Torture in Spanish Court
description: International lawyers have filed a criminal complaint against nine Syrian security and intelligence officials in a Spanish court, accusing them of torture and other human rights violations. It is the first case specifically citing members of Syrias government to be heard in a Western court.

title: Amazons Holiday Quarter Doesnt Match High Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Amazon showed the kind of growth over the holidays that most big companies would die for, as it continued to suck away sales from crumbling bricks-and-mortar retailers. But it was not enough.

description: We want to learn more about who is using marijuana in pregnancy, and why. Share your story with us here.

title: Pregnant Women Turn to Marijuana, Perhaps Harming Infants
description: During her pregnancy, she never drank alcohol or had a cigarette. But nearly every day, Stacey, then 24, smoked marijuana.

title: N.F.L. Players Association Opposes Trumps Immigration Order
description: HOUSTON  The N.F.L. Players Association said Thursday that it was opposed to President Trumps temporary ban on refugees and on immigrants from seven Muslim-majority countries.

title: Kevin Geer, Known for Stage Roles, Dies at 64
description: Kevin Geer, a prodigious character actor best known for his work in theater, including roles on Broadway in the 2004 revival of Twelve Angry Men and Warren Leights family drama Side Man, died on Jan. 25 at his home in Manhattan. He was 64.

title: Donald Trump and Lawmakers Confer on Imports and Tax Code
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump, at loggerheads with congressional Republicans over the best way to overhaul the tax code, may have come toward Capitol Hill on a key sticking point, the way imports should be taxed, after a meeting at the White House on Thursday, said Representative Kevin Brady, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

description: Dear Diary:

description: UNITED NATIONS  Nikki R. Haley, the new American ambassador to the United Nations, condemned Russia on Thursday for its recent aggressive actions in eastern Ukraine.

title: In an Age of Cybercrime, Low-Tech Thieves Target Mailboxes
description: The streets of Upper Manhattan were quiet, but a police officer saw two men standing in front of a blue mailbox at Broadway and Academy Street.

title: Whos Going to Be a Billionaire? The Biggest Winners of Snaps I.P.O.
description: One of the more reliable paths to becoming a billionaire over the past 20 years has been to build a dominant technology company and then to take it public. That trend has led to Google billionaires, Facebook billionaires and a whole class of mere multimillionaires too.

title: How Violence Undermined the Berkeley Protest
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  What do you do as a reporter when a protest begins? You cover it.

title: New York Police Dept. Agrees to Curb Stop-and-Frisk Tactics
description: The New York Police Department has agreed to curtail stop-and-frisk tactics in thousands of private apartment buildings under a settlement announced Thursday, ending the last in a series of stop-and-frisk lawsuits that fundamentally changed the citys approach to fighting street crime.

title: Tensions Between New and Old, Played Out at Ralph Lauren
description: When Stefan Larsson joined Ralph Lauren as its chief executive less than two years ago, to work beside the fashion houses founder, he had big ideas for transforming the stagnant brands offerings into must-have clothing for the 21st century.

title: Was That Search Illegal? Sometimes, Neil Gorsuch Ruled It Was
description: WASHINGTON  After a Kansas man was convicted of possessing and sending child pornography, he appealed to the United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit. The case came before a three-judge panel that included Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, who is now President Trumps Supreme Court nominee.

title: Wanted: One Republican With Integrity, to Defeat Betsy DeVos
description: This country needs a few good Republicans  one more would do  to rescue it from Betsy DeVos, one of President Trumps worst cabinet choices and his pick to run the Department of Education.

title: A Free Speech Battle at the Birthplace of a Movement at Berkeley
description: BERKELEY, Calif.  Fires burned in the cradle of free speech. Furious at a lecture organized on campus, demonstrators wearing ninja-like outfits smashed windows, threw rocks at the police and stormed a building. The speech? The university called it off.

title: White House Defends Commando Raid on Qaeda Branch in Yemen
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Thursday defended the planning and execution of a Special Operations raid in Yemen on Sunday  the first approved by President Trump since taking office  that left one American commando dead and three others injured, and most likely killed several civilians, including children.

title: Anarchists Respond to Trumps Inauguration, by Any Means Necessary
description: The videotaped sucker punch that staggered the white nationalist Richard Spencer on Inauguration Day quickly inspired mockery on social media. But it echoed loudly in an escalating confrontation between extreme ends of the political spectrum.

title: Soul-Searching at Clinton Foundation in Trump Era
description: Last summer, former President Bill Clinton pledged that if Hillary Clinton won the presidential election, he would avoid conflicts by stepping aside from many of his duties at the Clinton Foundation, restricting foreign donations to the charity and spinning off certain programs.

title: Melania Trumps Absence From Washington Raises Questions About Her Role
description: WASHINGTON  When President Trump traveled to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware this week to pay respects to a fallen member of the Navy SEALs, it was his daughter Ivanka  not his wife, Melania  who accompanied him.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: We tried to warn you, with Occupy. We understood that people were sick of the political system, which is fundamentally corrupt. People want something radically different.

title: Something Cold From Mars
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  I thought this was a fun Friday puzzle from a young contributor, with a handful of millennial neologisms  DRUNKDIAL, PITY PARTY and, yes, MANKINI among them  and some unusual cluing for old answers to boot. Im rarely speedy on Fridays and this one took me a while.

title: One Small Stroke for a 59 Is One Giant Leap for Golfers
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  After Adam Hadwin broke the 60-stroke mark at the par-72 La Quinta Country Club in California last month, he likened the feat to running the mile in under four minutes.

description: Ivanka Trump stilettos will soon be harder to find at Nordstrom.

title: How Arsenal and Arsne Wenger Bought Into Analytics
description: Neither Marouane Chamakh nor Park Chu-Young occupies a particularly prominent place in Arsenals history. The former, a dilettante Moroccan striker, spent three years at the club after joining in 2010. He scored only 14 goals, was packed off on loan to West Ham United, and then released to Crystal Palace.

title: U.S. Womens Team Restructures Union in Effort to Revive C.B.A. Talks
description: In small-group conversations and team meetings, in phone calls and text messages, the members of the United States womens national team came to a conclusion: If they were going to get the kind of collective bargaining agreement they wanted out of their stalled negotiations with U.S. Soccer, they would need to do more of the work themselves.

title: Baylor Football Was Black Hole of Misconduct, According to Court Filing
description: Several members of the Baylor University athletics department, including the fired football coach Art Briles, were dismissive of sexual assault accusations and attempted to keep such cases  and other criminal conduct  quiet, according to a court filing by the university on Thursday.

title: North Korean Leaders Top Enforcer Is Now the One Getting Purged
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The chief of North Koreas powerful secret police, long considered the right-hand man for the top leader, Kim Jong-un, has been dismissed on charges of corruption and abuse of power, the South Korean government said on Friday.

title: Whats on TV Friday: Drew Barrymore in Santa Clarita Diet
description: Drew Barrymore goes on a protein binge  and transforms from a frumpy housewife into a sexy zombie  in Santa Clarita Diet. A Bigger Splash, starring Tilda Swinton and plenty of enviable real estate, arrives for streaming on HBO. And Rebecca prepares to walk down the aisle in Crazy Ex-Girlfriend.

title: Word + Quiz: patent
Office of South Koreas Embattled Leader Blocks Search of Presidential Compound
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The office of President Park Geun-hye of South Korea blocked investigators from searching its compound on Friday, creating a standoff between Ms. Park, who argues that she is the victim of a political witch hunt, and a special prosecutor who has accused her of bribery.

description: President Trumps two-for-one deal  an executive order requiring federal agencies to eliminate at least two regulations for every new one issued  sounds more like a fast-food ad than a plan for governing.

title: Dont Let Republicans Steal the Seat
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans are in the middle of pulling off one of the great political heists in American history: the theft of a seat on the United States Supreme Court. And this theft, if successful, will have an enormous impact on the integrity of the Supreme Court and major issues from reproductive and labor rights to consumer and environmental protection.

title: Can the Democrats Be as Stubborn as Mitch McConnell?
description: In laying the groundwork recently for President Trumps nomination for the Supreme Court, Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, had this to say: What we hope would be that our Democratic friends will treat President Trumps nominees in the same way that we treated Clinton and Obama.

title: A Return to National Greatness
description: The Library of Congresss main building is one of the most magnificent buildings in Washington, or in the country. It was built in a pivotal, tumultuous time. During the 23 years in the late 19th century that it took to design and build the structure, industrialization transformed America. More people immigrated to America than in the previous 250 years combined.

title: Donald the Menace
description: For the past couple of months, thoughtful people have been quietly worrying that the Trump administration might get us into a foreign policy crisis, maybe even a war.

title: A Tyrants Ghost Guides Trump
description: The Man Who Would Be King signs his executive orders with a stagy flourish, waving thick leather binders that look like the menu at Beefsteak Charlies, as Bill Maher said. Take that, Muslims! Die, Obamacare! Were building a wall, Mexicans!

title: New Tensions With Iran
description: This editorial has been updated to reflect news developments.

title: Pedro Pascal: Making It at 41
description: LONDON  Pedro Pascal was a little lost.

title: Whats the Best Way to Heal a Broken Heart?
description: Have you ever broken up with someone  or had someone break up with you? Was it traumatic, regardless of who decided to end the relationship?

title: How to Walk on Hand Rails
description: One of the main principles of parkour is a repurposing of your environment, says Travis Graves, program director at American Parkour Academy, which promotes the discipline of running, jumping, climbing and moving in other ways through urban settings. We see things for their potential, not for their intended purpose. One way to start crossing those boundaries might be as simple as walking on a hand rail. Make sure its sturdy and stable. Wear shoes with thin soles or go barefoot. That gives you a more tactile feel and allows your feet to interact with the rail, Graves says. Being on a rail is similar to being on a balance beam, but because the former is thinner and usually round, your whole foot cannot be on top of the rail at once. That makes balance one of the biggest challenges, Graves says.

title: Judge John Hodgman Rules on a Sad Desk Lunch
description: Rachel writes: For the last five years, my romantic partner, Stephanie, has been making the same terrible lunch to bring to work. She has a longstanding habit of unceremoniously dropping a few slices of Tofurky between 2 pieces of frozen bread, using no condiments. She eats this depression sandwich alone in her cubicle. In the past she has expressed envy over the sandwiches I prepare for myself. I would like you to compel Stephanie to devote the energy required to make a better sandwich.

title: There Was a Great Want of Civility
description: This poem is from The Travelers Vade Mecum, a new anthology of poetry. The anthology takes its title from a 19th-century compendium of 8,466 numbered sentences designed to help travelers compose shorter telegrams; to use this system, the sender and the receiver of the telegram would each have a copy of the book and would communicate such useful messages as I am onboard a steamer ship bound for Paris by writing 45-Paris, or ominous ones like A sad accident has happened merely with 461. The anthologys editor, the poet and novelist Helen Klein Ross, chose some of these sentences and assigned them to poets to use as titles. The result is a wide-ranging, pleasurable overview of many different approaches in American poetry today. Selected by Matthew Zapruder

title: The Best and Latest in Crime Fiction
description: John Rebus is a downbeat version of his younger, scrappier self in RATHER BE THE DEVIL (Little, Brown, $27), the latest entry in Ian Rankins endlessly evolving series of Edinburgh police procedurals. Now retired from the force and hacking up his lungs with bronchitis or worse, the former homicide detective has gone a whole week without cigarettes. But every retired man needs a hobby, and for Rebus its brooding over unsolved cases like the 1978 murder of Maria Turquand, who was strangled at the venerable Caledonian Hotel while a party of rock musicians and their groupies was raging in the next room. And when the detective on that cold case is fished out of the harbor, the investigations intersect.

title: The 1.22.17 Issue
description: RE: FIRST WORDS

description: The Trump presidency has been a boon for dystopian novels, and now a pair of producers are hoping it will have the same effect on Broadway.

description: President Trump responded to the failed attack in Paris with his trademark understatement. Europe is not amused.

description: The University of California, Merced, rises apparition-like out of a landscape of cow pastures, cotton fields and grasslands. In the cool of the morning, the faint scent of manure, the olfactory signature of the Central Valley, hangs in the air.

title: The Secret to Sibling Success
description: Years ago, my younger brother and I attended the wedding of a childhood friend, held on a high floor of a stylish San Francisco hotel. We were standing by the floor-to-ceiling windows, joking with each other, when the sister of the groom approached.

title: Discovering the Lost Coast of Queens
description: A wave, of the development kind, finally seems to be forming along the edge of Queens where Astoria meets the East River.

title: Fillon Scandal Indicts, Foremost, Frances Political Elite
description: PARIS  The president of the National Assembly does it. The president of the Senate defends it. Dozens of rank-and-file parliamentarians do it, too. Hiring your spouse, son or sister in Frances Parliament is perfectly legal.

description: Just minutes after a federal judge blocked part of President Trumps immigration order on Saturday night, ruling that no one with a valid visa should be deported, someone was, according to court papers filed on Thursday.

title: Betsy DeVos, Pick for Secretary of Education, Is the Most Jeered
description: By most any measure, the secretary of education is one of the least powerful cabinet positions.

title: Harry Belafonte Knows a Thing or Two About New York
description: Harry Belafontes New York was a lot like yours and mine. He was born in Harlem, got his first singing gig through Lester Young, his first acting role in a company with Sidney Poitier and his first lessons in a class with Marlon Brando, Rod Steiger, Bea Arthur, Elaine Stritch and Tony Curtis. He met the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in a Harlem church basement through Adam Clayton Powell Jr., and met W. E. B. Du Bois through Paul Robeson; his uncle Lenny, who ran a numbers racket, introduced him to the elite of Harlems gangsters. He took Nelson Mandela to Yankee Stadium, planned an Amos and Andy movie with Robert Altman and, at 89, he was a co-chairman of the Womens March on Washington last month, along with Gloria Steinem, though his health kept him from the event.

title: Uber and Starbucks Protests Show Boycotts Need More Than a Hashtag
description: In the race to find someone  anyone  to lash out at over the immigration and travel restrictions ordered by President Trump last Friday, many consumers settled on an odd target: Uber. It had, supposedly, undercut prices for non-Uber taxis just as protesting taxi drivers went back to work. A boycott brigade formed almost immediately.

title: U.S. Starts Year With Job Surge, but Pay Gains Are Weak
description: If the surprisingly strong job gains in January revealed the economys resilience, they also exposed some of its stubborn weaknesses.

title: Assailant Near Louvre Is Shot by French Soldier
description: PARIS  A man armed with two large knives and shouting God is great in Arabic lunged at a military patrol near an entrance to the Louvre on Friday, causing little harm, but rattling a city already on edge over terrorist attacks and casting another shadow over its international image.

title: Teaching With: Animated Life: Pangea
description: This documentary tells the story of the polar explorer Alfred Wegener, the unlikely scientist behind continental drift theory. This film is part of the Op-Docs series Animated Life, which uses paper-puppet animation to explore pivotal moments of discovery, and the characters past and present who have driven us to see the world in new ways.

title: The Daily: Trump Trumps the Super Bowl
description: When Patriots quarterback Tom Brady cant make it through a pregame news conference without talking about our president, its official: Donald Trump overshadows everything. Even the Super Bowl.

description: A new online survey from YouGov details which countries Americans consider to be allies. Australia tops that list for Republicans.

title: Why Is a Poets First Collection So Important?
description: If youre an author who specializes in, say, writing about science for general readers, then your first book will be regarded by most people as ... the book you wrote first. That it was your inaugural effort will have no special significance; your work will be judged the way books are typically judged: as interesting or dull.

title: For the Disabled Traveler, Strategies for a Successful Trip
description: Terry Scott Cohen, 42, enjoys roller coasters, mushing in Alaska and tobogganing in the Pyrenees Mountains. Though he gets about in a motorized scooter, he has not let his myotonic dystrophy, a disease involving progressive muscle loss, curtail his travels. His father, Barry M. Cohen, 72, a retired industrial psychologist, acts as his travel companion, and together the two Floridians have written a book, Travel Near & Travel Far: Step Out of Your Disabled World! that provides both encouragement for disabled travelers and practical advice on navigating the world from a scooter or wheelchair. The elder Mr. Cohen recently discussed the book; here are excerpts from that conversation.

title: The Not-So-Secret War: Revisiting American Intervention in Laos
description: A GREAT PLACE TO HAVE A WARAmerica in Laos and the Birth of a Military CIABy Joshua Kurlantzick323 pp. Simon & Schuster. $28.

title: Mirrors for My Daughters Bookshelf
description: While fixing my 4-year-old daughters bookshelf, I noticed something missing on the glossy covers of her picture books: girls of color. There were talking cars, imaginary creatures and stories about white men, women and children. I started counting and discovered that only 4 percent of our books featured minorities as main characters, and only one was a black girl like my daughter.

title: Stylish Comfort in Notting Hill
description: Rooms from 179 (about $220).

title: In Meat-Heavy Chicago, a Shrine to Vegetables
description: Carl Sandburg may have famously labeled Chicago Hog Butcher for the World, but Bad Hunter, in a former meatpacking district, celebrates the citys culinary history by highlighting plants.

description: Not long after Daniel Weisman met Elizabeth Zuckerman. he decided it was time to leave his Los Angeles lifestyle behind. The couple were married on Jan. 14 in Park City, Utah.

description: Elizabeth Zuckerman and Daniel Weisman were in full rescue mode when they met for a first date in 2014, at a Halloween fund-raising event for an animal shelter in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Trump Has Provocative Words for Allies. Congress Does Damage Control.
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump has been in office for barely two weeks, but Congress is already in diplomatic damage control.

title: An Evolving Sports City, Atlanta Chases a Championship
description: ATLANTA  The most arresting vista in town comes into view around a curve on westbound Freedom Parkway, on the periphery of downtown. The road crests just before it intersects Boulevard, at a traffic light that always seems to glow red, as if to allow motorists a minute to savor the panorama before them.

title: Behind the Best Sellers: Girl Before Author JP Delaney on Pseudonyms and the Limits of Marie Kondo
description: The Life-Changing Terror of Tidying Up: He may be an insufferable, affected, narcissistic creep, but hes also a genius. Thats how Chip Kidd summed up the architect villain of Death by Design, his 2012 Batman story with Dave Taylor, in whats surely a nod to all the insufferable, affected, narcissistic architects in literary history  even the heroes: Howard Roark, anyone? Certainly the description fits Edward Monkford, the tightly wound minimalist at the center of The Girl Before, a psychological thriller by JP Delaney that debuts at No.5 on the hardcover fiction list. Monkford rents his showpiece house only to alluring young women (who dont always survive), and he rivals Marie Kondo in his aversion to clutter: The review in the daily New York Times was headlined, ominously, He Doesnt Like It When You Leave Your Shampoo Out.

title: Octavia Spencer Condemns Trump Followers Who Reject Hidden Figures
description: The past year has been a momentous one for the Oscar-winning actress Octavia Spencer, one of the stars of Hidden Figures, based on the true story of three black female mathematicians working at the nations space agency in the Jim Crow South.

title: Cedric Bru of Taulia on Building Trust Through Vulnerability
description: This interview with Cedric Bru, the C.E.O. of Taulia, a maker of invoicing software, has been edited for space and clarity.

title: Kirsten Gillibrand and the Anti-Trump Left: 2020 Foresight?
description: When David A. Paterson, then governor of New York, appointed Kirsten E. Gillibrand to fill Hillary Clintons Senate seat in 2009, there was little feeling that she would become a key voice in a movement of resistance from the left. As a Blue Dog congressional Democrat representing an upstate district, Ms. Gillibrand had an A rating from the National Rifle Association. She had an uptown bearing but talked about the guns she kept tucked under her bed. Working as a young lawyer, she defended the tobacco industry.

description: French soldiers shot and wounded an assailant carrying a blade and bags after he lunged at one of them in the underground shopping area at the museum in Paris.

title: Donald Trump: Day 15
description: Whats next on the agenda?

title: Oscar-Nominated Movies, Sometimes Streaming Near You
description: One common complaint about the Oscars addresses the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences perceived tendency to honor movies that ostensibly no one has seen. In some cases, the complainants are talking about prestige films that didnt do a lot at the box office. A couple of months ago, I was listening to a podcast featuring two of the West Coasts more colorful Oscar commentators, and one of them excitedly put La La Land in the category of films no one has seen. At the time, the movie, a critical favorite among festivalgoers, had not yet been released. Oscar commentators can be very silly people.

description: Iran will bar the United States wrestling team from a major international meet this month in response to President Trumps order severely limiting travel from several Muslim-majority countries, including Iran.

description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Oil Spill Near Chennai, India, Threatens Wildlife
description: NEW DELHI  Thousands of volunteers and Indian Coast Guard personnel were working on Friday to clean sludge from shores near the southern city of Chennai nearly a week after an oil spill that activists said could have dire repercussions for wildlife and fishery.

title: This Organ Shakes Up Oberlin
description: Its 1 a.m. on a Friday and a few hundred Oberlin College students are sprawled on the floor. This is the moment theyve been waiting for all night. Its why they rushed the stage. The floor begins to rumble and shake beneath them.

title: Jim Mattis Says U.S. Is Shoulder to Shoulder With Japan
description: TOKYO  Defense Secretary Jim Mattis assured Japans prime minister on Friday that the United States would stand by its mutual defense treaty with the country, despite statements by President Trump during last years campaign that suggested he might pull back from American security commitments in Asia.

title: Travel Ban Drives Wedge Between Iraqi Soldiers and Americans
description: BAGHDAD  Capt. Ahmed Adnan al-Musawe had survived another day battling Islamic State fighters in Mosul last weekend when he heard startling news: The new American president had temporarily barred Iraqis from entering the United States and wanted tougher vetting.

title: Run. Eat a Doughnut. Run.
description: This weekend in Raleigh, N.C., some 8,000 runners are expected to line up for a road race, run through town and  eat doughnuts.

title: Kellyanne Conway Admits Bowling Green Massacre Error
description: Kellyanne Conway, the adviser to President Trump who coined the phrase alternative facts, is facing another round of criticism and fact-checking after she falsely spoke of a Bowling Green massacre by Iraqi refugees. She acknowledged and corrected her statement Friday morning on Twitter.

title: Ricky Gervais Goes Back to The Office
description: To American audiences, the British comedian Ricky Gervais is known as an irreverent stand-up and the provocative, four-time host of the Golden Globes, as well as a creator and star of shows like Extras, Lifes Too Short and Derek. Thats all thanks to his breakout series, The Office, which had its BBC debut in 2001 and starred Mr. Gervais as David Brent, the tactless and overbearing manager of a paper company being recorded by a documentary crew.

title: MoMA Protests Trump Entry Ban by Rehanging Work by Artists from Muslim Nations
description: In one of the strongest protests yet by a major cultural institution against President Trumps executive order on immigration, the Museum of Modern Art has rehung part of its permanent collection with works by artists from some of the majority-Muslim nations whose citizens are blocked from entering the United States.

title: Profits? Nice, but for These Investors, Conscience Matters More
description: Seth Holehouse, who owns an auction house in New York City, has focused his investments on renewable energy and recycled products. He has done so for the last five years  despite steadily losing money on the strategy.

title: A Dreamlike Western With a Different Kind of Hero
description: DAYS WITHOUT ENDBy Sebastian Barry259 pp. Viking. $26.

title: A Fathers Wrenching Memoir of Death, Guilt and Reckoning
description: DISASTER FALLSA Family StoryBy Stphane Gerson258 pp. Crown. $26.

title: Why I Wont Vote for Betsy DeVos
description: WASHINGTON  Our nation recognized early in its history that public education is a necessary foundation for a democracy. Its critical that we continue to support a strong public education system that prepares our young people, all of them, to participate in our democracy and compete on a fair footing in the work force.

title: Friday Mailbag: News Cycles That Wont Stop Spinning
description: Marches have been the theme of the past couple weekends. There was the womens march in Washington and around the world two weekends ago. And last weekend there was the March for Life, an annual protest against abortion. The Times called the people who marched in the latter march, anti-abortion marchers in two headlines, to the ire of several readers.

title: The Weekly Health Quiz: Hormone Blockers, Hair Growth and How to Apologize
description: Test your knowledge of this weeks health news.

title: Protect Our Childrens Brains
description: IN the fall, I began to research an article that I gave the working title The Last Days of Chlorpyrifos. A widely used pesticide, chlorpyrifos affects humans as well as the bugs it kills. Back in the halcyon days before the election, the optimism of the title seemed warranted. After years of study, the Environmental Protection Agency had announced in October 2015 that it could no longer vouch for the safety of chlorpyrifos on food.

title: Four Strappy Sandals With Modest, Chunky Heels
description: Low-heel shoes that are as grandma-chic as they are comfortable.

title: Rugbys Tackling Rules Arent Changing, but Referees Enforcement of Them Is
description: LONDON  Producing more of the same is what the Six Nations Championship, the biggest event in European rugby union, is mostly about.

title: U.S. Imposes New Sanctions on Iran Over Missile Test
description: WASHINGTON  New sanctions that the Trump administration imposed on Friday to punish Tehrans latest ballistic missile test marked the beginning of what officials called the end of an era in which the United States was too tolerant of Irans bad behavior.

title: Trump Said the Unemployment Rate Wasnt Real. Here Are Some Other Options.
description: With the January jobs report released Friday by the Labor Department, we know that President Trump took office amid a relatively low unemployment rate (it ticked up to 4.8 percent in January), strong job growth (227,000 positions added that month) and weak wage growth (average hourly earnings up 0.1 percent in January and 2.5 percent over the past year).

title: New Life for Dracula
description: In 1898, Bram Stokers Dracula was translated for the first time, into Hungarian. Just a couple of years later, it was published in Icelandic. But it turns out the Icelandic rendering was much more than a translation; it was a radically different version of the story. In a foreword to Powers of Darkness, an annotated English-language edition of that version, Dacre Stoker, the great-grandnephew of Bram, says the author could not have been immune to the influences of the Icelandophiles who surrounded him, people who had traveled to the country and studied its myths and literature.

title: How David Became Goliath: The Secret of Israels Military Success
description: THE WEAPON WIZARDSHow Israel Became a High-Tech Military SuperpowerBy Yaakov Katz and Amir BohbotIllustrated. 288 pp. St. Martins Press. $27.99.

title: How the Model Andreja Pejic Spends Her Sundays: Yoga and a Pig Out Brunch
description: The model Andreja Pejic had become a name in the fashion industry while she was still male and named Andrej. In 2014, after a career of gender-fluid appearances on the catwalk for Marc Jacobs and Jean-Paul Gaultier, she underwent gender-reassignment surgery, which made her star burn only brighter: Ms. Pejic became the first transgender model to be profiled in Vogue and  to land a campaign with a major cosmetics company, Make Up for Ever. As she prepares for New York Fashion Week, Feb. 9 to 16, Ms. Pejic, 25, who lives in the East Village, spends her Sundays drinking tea, going to yoga class and eating a brunch with the works. NEESHA ARTER

title: Brady vs. Dunkin: Rank the New England Institutions
description: The Patriots have ascended to bona fide New England institution. But have they surpassed the Red Sox? Or Dunkin Donuts? Certainly not Paul Revere, right? Rank your favorites here.

title: Are You College-Ready?
description: Place yourself, with sample math questions from the newly revised Accuplacer.

title: Trying to Solve a Bigger Math Problem
description: Algebra is clearly a stumbling block for many incoming college students. Nearly 60 percent of community college students end up in remedial math  thats more than double the number in remedial English. Four-year public colleges are not far behind. According to government studies, 40 percent of their incoming students take at least one remedial class; 33 percent are in math.

title: Macys Is Said to Receive Takeover Approach by Hudsons Bay
description: The Macys of today grew from the union of several great names in American retailing, including its namesake chain, Bloomingdales and Marshall Fields.

title: Zenith, the Sleepy Watch Brand, Seeks a Modern Makeover
description: He looks like a Bond villain, markets with the zeal of P. T. Barnum and is regarded as a visionary after guiding rejuvenations of Blancpain, Hublot and Tag Heuer. To the extent that the Swiss watch industry has a Steve Jobs, Jean-Claude Biver is it.

title: Virtual Reality Has Arrived in the Art World. Now What?
description: When the world outside looks frightful, you might be tempted to put on the blinders.

title: Josh Miller, Obamas Digital Product Director, Joins Thrive Capital
description: Josh Miller, who was a member of the White House Office of Digital Strategy under President Barack Obama, has joined Thrive Capital, a venture capital firm run by the investor Joshua Kushner.

title: Navigating the Many Offers of Free Tax Help
description: This year, there are numerous ways to prepare and file income tax returns free of charge  but the variety of features and qualifying criteria is dizzying. So it is important for filers to slow down and make sure the programs they choose are really the ones they want.

title: A Quick Guide to the Foreign-Language Oscar Nominees
description: The race for the Oscar for best foreign-language film usually doesnt get much attention, considering the categorys scope. But this year you may be aware of one nominee, the Iranian director Asghar Farhadi, who is among the prominent artists to be affected by President Trumps ban on visas for travelers from predominantly Muslim countries. Mr. Farhadis drama The Salesman is one of five films up for the foreign-language film statuette.

title: A Move to the West Village for a Good School
description: This is a story about how the hunt for a good public school can move a New York City family out of their home.

title: Uber Chiefs Email to Employees
description: Email from Travis Kalanick, chief of Uber, announcing that he was stepping down from President Trumps economic advisory council.

title: 10 Things to Do in NYC Now
description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

title: Top Sales Include Billy Bushs Chelsea Townhouse
description: The Manhattan real estate market got off to a strong start in 2017, with the closed sale of the second most expensive penthouse at the supertall 432 Park Avenue and a spurt of activity at other new developments.

title: What You Need to Know About Trumps Statement on Israeli Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  In the two weeks since President Trump took office, an emboldened Israeli government cast off international criticism and approved the construction of thousands of new settler homes in the occupied West Bank and East Jerusalem. And Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu announced plans to build an entirely new West Bank settlement, despite a commitment to the United States dating to the 1990s that Israel would not do so.

title: Were hiring four journalists to shape Opinion video
description: Help The New York Times inform, provoke and challenge our audience.

title: Januarys Most Popular Listings
description: The most viewed listings for the month of January on The New York Times Find a Home site included a stunning Frank Lloyd Wright-designed home in Connecticut, a colonial in Westchester County and apartments on the Upper West and Upper East Sides of Manhattan.

title: Bernie Sanders Talks Tuition, Free for All
description: Senator Bernie Sanders may not have succeeded in his effort to become president, but his campaign to place the cost of college higher up on the national agenda seems to be gaining momentum. In January, he was by Andrew Cuomos side when the governor proposed that New Yorkers with family income under $125,000 be able to attend state colleges tuition-free. Then Rhode Island announced its own proposal, covering two years but open to all in-state students no matter their income. At the federal level, with a Republican-controlled Congress, prospects for similar legislation are dim. During her confirmation hearing as education secretary, Betsy DeVos told Mr. Sanders: Theres nothing in life thats truly free. Somebodys going to pay for it. Still, the senator from Vermont continues to visit campuses and to push for federal legislation that would make tuition at public colleges free for all.

title: Daily Report: Getting Close to Trump Is Risky in Tech
description: The technology industry is not exactly known for following the rules. Move fast. Break things. Apologize later. The industrys clichs dont project compliance.

title: To Lock or Not to Lock the Screen
description: Q. How do I turn off the password protection on my phone? Its annoying each time to re-enter it, and I realized that if I lose my phone and someone finds it, they wont have a way to contact me.

title: The Story of Sweet Marie and an Earlier Womens Protest
description: Q. A hundred years before the Womens March on Washington, another womens uprising took place, in which Marie Ganz, known as Sweet Marie, played a leading role. Who was she and where did she get her nickname?

title: The Trump Effect: Whats an Investor to Do?
description: When Donald J. Trump won the presidential election, investors seemed positively giddy about what he was going to do to improve the nations economy. Believing that his promises to reduce corporate taxes and curtail costly regulations would unleash economic growth, investors pushed stock indexes to new heights.

title: An Unusually Artful Task Lamp
description: Thomas Edison is celebrated for his invention of the practical light bulb, but in truth, this came roughly a year after a British chemist named Joseph Swan debuted a similar bulb in 1878. Edisons innovation was longer lasting, evolving to illuminate the modern world, but Swans elegant lamp prototype, which burned for only about 40 hours, was a shapely marvel. Today, the designer Kelly Wearstler has created a minimalist task lamp in antique burnished brass that echoes his ephemeral creation. A can-shaped shade on an adjustable arm hovers above a base of cylindrical white Carrara marble.

description: Subscribe: iTunes | Google Play Music

title: Ruth Negga Is This Award Seasons Fashion Darling
description: Every awards season, fashion seems to fall head over ears in love with a star. Last year, it was Alicia Vikander with her balletic grace; this year, it is Ruth Negga with her from-another-era appeal.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Ren Redzepi
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the Danish chef Ren Redzepi, co-owner of the Copenhagen restaurant Noma, who shares his list exclusively with T.

title: Misophonia Sufferers: Scientists May Have Found the Root of Your Pain
description: Popcorn munching. Soup slurping. Nose sniffling. Or, simply, breathing.

description: It was 12:48 a.m. Saturday morning, just hours after President Trump signed the immigration travel ban, when I heard a text message alert. I was half-asleep in my Brooklyn apartment and almost didnt pick up the phone, assuming it was a friend at a bar or a party wanting to meet, when I was in for the night.

title: A Savory, Tender Gnocchi Poised for Success
description: Gnocchi, those savory little dumplings, are frequently offered as a first course in Italian restaurants, as an alternative to a pasta course. Other times, a larger portion may make a fine hot lunch, or just a few gnocchi can round out a main course, sidled up to a saucy braised veal shank.

title: Top 20 Fields for Internships: Get Your Skills On
description: This is high season for securing a summer internship, an essential talent pipeline for employers and steppingstone for students. Postings peak in March, with 30,443 advertised positions in March 2016 (if you dont have anything by May, youre probably out of luck). But before sending that rsum, take a good hard look at whats on it.

title: When Burberrys New Designer Was at Givenchy: 10 Noteworthy Red Carpet Moments
description: Riccardo Tisci has dressed fashion favorites like Beyonc, Selena Gomez and Rooney Mara in Givenchy at major events. Heres a look back.

title: Trump Moves to Roll Back Obama-Era Financial Regulations
description: President Trump on Friday moved to chisel away at the Obama administrations legacy on financial regulation, announcing steps to revisit the rules enacted after the 2008 financial crisis and to back away from a measure intended to protect consumers from bad investment advice.

title: What Baroque Venice Can Teach Us About Modern Politics
description: For New Yorkers seeking temporary respite from political Twitter storms, Carnegie Hall is usually a safe space. And its special festival La Serenissima: Music and Arts from the Venetian Republic may seem particularly appealing. With a sumptuous red-and-gold Carnival mask adorning the marketing materials, and a program promising liberal amounts of Vivaldi, the festival, which runs through Feb. 21 at Carnegie (and elsewhere), virtually guarantees escape.

title: Fiduciary Rule Is Now in Question. Whats Next for Investors.

title: H. Boyd Woodruff, Microbiologist Who Paved Way for Antibiotics, Dies at 99
description: H. Boyd Woodruff, a farmers son whose groundbreaking research enabled fellow scientists to harvest an arsenal of lifesaving antibiotics from ordinary dirt, died on Jan. 19 at his home in Watchung, N.J. He was 99.

description: To the Editor:

description: A diversity committee in Westport, Conn., a wealthy coastal town that was 93 percent white as of 2010, asked high school students earlier this year to reflect on the role of white privilege in their lives.

title: Iran Treads Cautiously With Trump. So Far.
description: TEHRAN  Until President Trumps inauguration, Irans clerics felt comfortable leading worshipers in a chorus of Death to America while simultaneously signing a $16.6 billion deal with Boeing. Now, the establishment is treading carefully, with even most hard-liners concerned that the smallest provocation could lead to military conflict.

title: Snaps Plan Is Most Unfriendly to Outsiders
description: Snap Inc. is aiming to adopt the most shareholder-unfriendly governance in an initial public offering, ever.

description: Robert O. Work, the veteran defense official retained as deputy secretary by President Trump, calls them his A.I. dudes. The breezy moniker belies their serious task: The dudes have been a kitchen cabinet of sorts, and have advised Mr. Work as he has sought to reshape warfare by bringing artificial intelligence to the battlefield.

description: In his first exhibition, New York Photographs, the 30-year-old street photographer Daniel Weiss documents the kind of weird moments that may be disappearing from the city.

description: The New York street photographer searches for character amid the chain-store sterility of a vanishing city. Daniel Weiss, 30, has an eye especially attuned to chronicling the impressions of a coarser New York.

description: If Elena, 14, is sent back to her country, she may be murdered.

title: This Is What a Refugee Looks Like
description: An early poll finds that President Trumps suspension of the refugee program was popular. I think thats partly because many Americans fear terrorism and the word refugee unfairly and inaccurately conjures an image of a prospective terrorist.

title: Year of the Rooster

The New York Philharmonic held a Chinese New Year celebration on Jan. 31 at David Geffen Hall that featured lion dancers. The 57th Quadrille Ball, which benefits the Germanistic Society of America, was held Jan. 28 at the Pierre hotel. And the National Cares Mentoring Movement held its second gala on Jan. 30 at Cipriani 42nd Street.

title: Is Trumps Foreign Policy Inept, or Radical? Its Both
description: In just two weeks in office, President Trump has embarked on a foreign policy that is literally all over the map: insulting the Australian prime minister, threatening a trade war with Mexico and imposing a ham-handed refugee ban that has drawn global condemnation.

title: The Playlist: Mariah Carey Shakes It Off, and Depeche Mode Looks for Revolution
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos  and anything else that strikes them as intriguing. You can listen to this playlist on Spotify here. Like this Playlist? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com, and sign up for our Louder newsletter here.

title: Norman Rockwells Four Freedoms Paintings to Go on Tour
description: Norman Rockwells most famous paintings are going on tour.

title: The Game Is On. Can You Please Take the Politics Outside?
description: On Sunday, President Trump will continue one of President Obamas Super Bowl traditions: a televised pregame interview, in this case with Bill OReilly of Fox News. While Mr. Trump is rarely one to shun the cameras, on this day I hope he will reconsider, and give the nation an opportunity to enjoy the game free of his presence.

title: Almond Cakes With Chocolate or Cherry

title: A Cupcake Confident in Its Own Skin
description: Its rare to see a naked cupcake.

title: How This London Troupe Takes You to the Heart of Dance
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Sometimes dance fills the eyes with tears, changes our breathing or makes us laugh  but why? The dancers arent depicting emotion, yet we find ourselves powerfully moved. On Thursday night at the Alexander Kasser Theater at Montclair State University, the dancers of the Richard Alston Dance Company, the London troupe that revisits the New York area about once every two years, caused a gamut of emotion, just by taking us to the heart of dance itself.

title: One Kitchen Done Three Ways
description: Renovating a kitchen can seem like a daunting proposition. Figuring out the best layout, style and finishes generally depends on your taste and circumstances, including what you can afford, how you plan to use the space and whether you plan to host frequent dinner parties or cook for yourself. Consider how three neighbors living in the same apartment complex in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, created three very different spaces out of the same basic B-Line kitchen.

title: The Neighbors Renovation
description: In one apartment complex, three very different spaces made out of the same basic B-Line kitchen.

title: E.U. Vows to Slow Migration on Sea Route That Claimed Thousands of Lives
description: VALLETTA, Malta  European Union leaders pledged on Friday to slow the movement of African migrants crossing the Mediterranean in a desperate and often deadly bid to escape war, chaos and poverty.

title: Review: In Rings, Best Not Go to the Videotape
description: Rings, the latest sequel in the franchise that began with the Japanese film Ringu, is short on outright frights, but some effort certainly went into the storytelling. For one thing, by the time this ones over, fans will know a lot more about the mysterious Samara, the dead girl who continues to terrify the living via a grainy videotape. And those nearing or in college  the demographic being aimed at here  will learn an important lesson: Beware of any professor who tries to recruit you for a research study.

title: The Met Operas Rusalka Is a Dark, Sexy Hit
description: The Metropolitan Operas new production of Dvoraks Rusalka may be the unlikeliest hit of the season, a staging that takes operas answer to The Little Mermaid fairy tale and turns it into an almost shockingly dark, sexy drama. The mysterious look of the production, fantastical and ominous, combines with the sensual singing of a handsome cast to create a romantic energy rare at the Met  or at any opera house.

title: Dore Ashton, Art Critic Who Embraced and Inhabited Modernism, Dies at 88
description: Dore Ashton, an art historian and critic who wrote some of the earliest and most insightful histories of Abstract Expressionism and the leading painters of the New York School, died on Monday in the Bronx. She was 88.

title: Flying? Bad Romance? What to Expect From Lady Gagas Super Bowl Halftime Show
description: Speculation about what will happen when Lady Gaga takes the stage as the main performer at the Super Bowl halftime show on Sunday has been furious: Has the N.F.L. asked her to avoid talking politics? Will Beyonc join her onstage? Will she cut a hole in Houstons NRG Stadium and fly in through the roof?

title: Rohingya Face Campaign of Terror in Myanmar, U.N. Finds
description: GENEVA  Members of Myanmars Army and the police have slaughtered hundreds of men, women and children, gang-raped women and girls, and forced as many as 90,000 Rohingya Muslims from their homes, according to a United Nations report released on Friday.

title: Violence at Berkeley and Freedom of Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: Snap as a Camera Company? I.P.O Raises Comparisons to GoPro
description: The parent of the Snapchat smartphone app thinks it is a camera company. Its almost as if its initial public offering filing on Thursday  which may raise up to $3 billion and leave the company valued at up to $25 billion  was somehow confused with GoPros from a few years ago, when the camera-hardware maker said it was in the media business.

title: Nicki Minaj Scolds Shoe Designer for Ignoring Her
description: Another day, another social media feud. On Friday morning, Nicki Minaj took to both Twitter and Instagram to call out Giuseppe Zanotti, an Italian luxury shoe brand, for using her name in its designs and tapping into her fan base without offering her payment or a creative collaboration in exchange.

description: This weeks properties include a five-bedroom in Scarsdale, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Huntington, N.Y.

description: OTTAWA  Just over a year after he became prime minister with promises of inclusion, optimism and internationalism, Justin Trudeau unexpectedly finds himself dealing with a mercurial American president who largely rejects those values.

description: An idea is a good thing, Ken Downing, the fashion director of Neiman Marcus, said on Tuesday, as he bolted in his biker jacket and skinny jeans from one show to another. But a theme can scare me running away.
