title: Our Articles on the Attacks Trump Says the Media Didnt Cover
description: The White House has issued a list of 78 terrorist attacks, saying most were underreported. The Trump administration, under fire for immigration restrictions and other policies it says are designed to curb terrorism, has portrayed the news media and other institutions as playing down the threat.

title: Biden Gets a Job, and Obama Goes Kitesurfing
description: For anyone wondering how former President Barack Obama is adjusting to life under the Trump administration, know this: He seems to be doing just fine.

title: Is There A Trump Bubble?
description: Everyone knows that stocks and interest rates have soared since the election; at the same time, if you arent worried about erratic policies from the Tweeter-in-chief, youre really not paying attention. So are markets getting it all wrong?

title: Dodd-Frank Rollback May Fall Short of G.O.P. Hopes
description: American bankers are suddenly full of hope. They reckon that President Trump will roll back the 2010 Dodd-Frank reforms, enacted to avoid a repeat of the 2008 financial crisis. Yet the presidents executive order calling for a review, signed on Friday, does little thats concrete. Any talk of diluting the rules has Democrats howling.

title: Neither Snow Nor Rain
description: Inclement weather did not dampen these New Yorkers style during past Fashion Weeks.

title: The Resurgence of the Arts in a Tumultuous Time
description: To the Editor:

title: Revisiting The Fairys Kiss, a Ballet About an Artists Destiny
description: There are ballets that choreographers return to again and again, fine tuning and recalibrating, as if trying to get at something essential they missed before. The Russian-American choreographer Alexei Ratmansky first tried his hand at The Fairys Kiss, a ballet based on Hans Christian Andersens The Ice Maiden, in 1994, when he was in his 20s. He has just completed his third version, this time for Miami City Ballet, where it will  premiere on Friday.

title: Early Grades for President Trump
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion vs. Winter: Who Wins?
description: Postal workers arent the only ones who complete their appointed rounds no matter the weather. The fashion tribe, too, bundles up against the bracing winds and gingerly navigates the snowdrifts and icy puddles that can often accompany the (ironically timed) spring/summer shows of New York Fashion Week each February. They just do it with more style.

title: Why Teen TV Is the Cure For the Prestige TV Blues
description: Add shows to your Watchlist with a single click on any of the linked titles below.

title: Tornadoes Tear Through New Orleans and Surrounding Areas
description: At least three tornadoes ripped through the New Orleans metropolitan area on Tuesday  with one touching down inside the city itself  damaging homes, snapping trees and power lines and injuring at least a dozen people.

title: Alissa Bennetts Dead Is Better
description: The writer and Team Gallery director shares scenes from the making of her zine, which focuses on deceased celebrities.

title: This Gallery Director Is Obsessed With Dead Celebrities
description: The writer and Team Gallery director Alissa Bennett never thought all the hours she spent devouring shows like Dateline and True Crime with Aphrodite Jones and the comment boards of findadeath.com would pay off. That is, until a chance run-in with independent publisher Frank Haines set off a chain reaction that led to the first issue of Dead Is Better, a biannual zine cataloging Bennetts morbid curiosities. I remember many years ago, my sons father said to me, This is your art, this is what you should do, Bennett recalls. I always thought it was a voyeuristic, shameful pastime, so it was a shock for me to have someone say that this vast repository of crime knowledge could go somewhere.

title: Joost van der Westhuizen, South African Rugby Legend, Dies at 45
description: Joost van der Westhuizen, one of South Africas greatest rugby players, who is best remembered for his part in a 1995 World Cup victory immortalized in a 2009 movie, died on Monday in Johannesburg. He was 45.

title: Oscar-Nominated Shorts: A Closer Look
description: Images from the 2017 Oscar-nominated shorts program.

title: Daily Provisions Opens Next to Union Square Cafe
description: DAILY PROVISIONS Coffee and food to eat in or take out are sold next to Union Square Cafe from what may be about the smallest restaurant David Rockwell ever designed  some people have more spacious kitchens in their apartments. But Daily Provisions is extremely well tailored, done in marine blue wainscoting with marble counters and tables, a few seats and shelves full of freshly baked breads, glazed and sugared crullers, cookies and croissants flecked with everything spices and filled with cream cheese. The chef, Carmen Quagliata, is baking big, well-burnished gougres stuffed with eggs or spinach, eggs and ham, and bronzing chickens on the rotisserie. Sandwiches are also sold, and the beverages include wine, beer and cider, though its open only until 6 p.m.: 103 East 19th Street, 212-488-1505, dailyprovisionsnyc.com.

title: New York Tries to Revive Garment Industry, Outside the Garment District
description: Like generations of garment workers before him, Max Hernandez came to New York City to get his start behind a sewing machine.

title: Plain Old Vaping Gives Way to Dripping Among Teenagers, Study Says
description: Teenagers have found a new way to worry their parents. Never mind plain old vaping  now, its all about dripping.

title: Corruption Scandal Ensnares Leaders of Peru and Colombia
description: LIMA, Peru  A corruption scandal in Latin America wound its way through the political establishments of two countries on Tuesday as Perus attorney general issued an arrest warrant for a former president and Colombian prosecutors said their presidents campaign might have received questionable donations.

title: Stephen Schwarzmans Bad Business Advice
description: For devotees of President Trump, the first gathering on Friday of his business council, which featured 17 executives, may have looked like a colorized version of Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, but for those focusing exclusively on the rapport between the two leaders, it resembled Goodfellas.

title: Cardinal Dolan, Fuming Over Archdioceses Rich Image, Vacations at Mansion
description: SLOATSBURG, N.Y.  The luxurious home, given to the Archdiocese of New York in December 2015, is an eight-bedroom, 10,000-square-foot manor house on seven lakefront acres here, with a private tennis court, outdoor pool and 70-foot indoor lap pool that resembles a Venetian canal.

title: Tornado Rips Through New Orleans
description: Tornadoes struck the New Orleans area on Tuesday, and residents caught some of the dramatic moments on video.

title: Irrational Coal Plants May Hamper Chinas Climate Change Efforts
description: YINING, China  When scientists and environmental scholars scan the grim industrial landscape of China, a certain coal plant near the rugged Kazakhstan border stands out.

title: How to Summon the Comic (!) Spirit of Martha Graham
description: Martha Graham, the modern dance matriarch, didnt make too many wildly funny pieces. But her little-known ballet Punch and the Judy, which told the story of a woman (danced by Graham) and her unfaithful husband (danced by Erick Hawkins), had audiences laughing in a good way at its 1941 premiere.

title: Sothebys Files Second Lawsuit Over Works It Calls Fake
description: Sothebys has filed a second lawsuit related to the sale of works originally attributed to European old master painters that it now says are forgeries.

title: What Were Reading
description: New York Times reporters and editors are highlighting great stories from around the web. You can receive What Were Reading by email, and let us know how you like it at wwr@nytimes.com.

title: The 51-50 Vote to Confirm DeVos
description: Betsy DeVos had one of the most contentious confirmations in history. Calls inundated the Capitol, disrupting the Senates voice mail system. But, in a historic tiebreaking vote, Ms. DeVos became the next education secretary.

title: Oscar-Nominated Shorts: Unsung but Worth Your Time
description: If you need a distraction from fighting about La La Land, cheering at Hidden Figures or weeping about Moonlight  all of which might have been distracting you from other things  there are 15 Oscar-nominated movies quietly soliciting your attention, along with that of the academy voters. The short-film nominees are often unsung awards-season highlights, too easily overlooked except for office-pool balloting purposes. This is a shame, since in about the time it would take to watch Arrival three times or Toni Erdmann twice, you could take a remarkably wide-ranging tour of world cinema.

title: Review: George Rose, From His Stage Life to His Unhappy End
description: If you are a theater fanatic, you know who George Rose was. If you were alive and going to New York theater in the 1970s and 80s, you may have even seen him radiating contagious joy in My Fair Lady, as the saucy Alfred P. Doolittle relishing the prospect of a little bit of luck. Or matching wits with Kevin Kline in The Pirates of Penzance. Or winning his second Tony Award as the M.C. in The Mystery of Edwin Drood, his final show.

title: Live Analysis: Oral Arguments on Trumps Immigration Order
description: Live analysis from Times reporters of the oral arguments in the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals on President Trumps targeted travel ban.

title: Hes 101, Shes 32, and Its the End of the World
description: AUTUMNBy Ali Smith260 pages. Pantheon. $24.95.

title: Executive Orders, Betsy DeVos: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Issues Facing Republicans in Replacing Affordable Care Act
description: WASHINGTON  Ever since Democrats began pushing the Affordable Care Act through Congress more than seven years ago, Republicans have been trying to come up with an alternative. Candid conversations leaked from a conclave of Republican lawmakers in Philadelphia last month, and public comments since, show they are nowhere near agreement.

title: Ali Smith: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Autumn ranks Invitation to a Beheading among the great books: Nabokov treats us to, then liberates us from, the bad farce of totalitarianism. What a blast.

title: What You Should Watch Tonight
description: The Challenge, 9 p.m., MTV (Season Premiere)

title: Broadways Bathroom Problem: Have to Go? Hurry Up, or Hold It
description: A revolution is taking place on Broadway, and not just at Hamilton.

title: Times Names Wall Street Journal Editor to Its Masthead
description: Rebecca Blumenstein, deputy editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, has been named a deputy managing editor of The New York Times, one of the top leadership positions at the newspaper.

title: The Comforts of the Betsy DeVos War
description: In these distinctly abnormal times for the republic, with Donald Trump in the White House and a group of unprepared revolutionaries around him, one must be grateful for small doses of normalcy and politics as usual. Thank heavens, then, for Senate Democrats, who just gave us the most predictable of spectacles: a liberal holy war against Betsy DeVos, just confirmed as the new secretary of education by Mike Pences tiebreaking vote.

title: Decade After Crisis, No Resolution for Fannie and Freddie
description: Fannie Mae, the gigantic government-sponsored mortgage service entity, has guaranteed $1 billion of debt backed by Invitation Homes, the single-family rental business owned by the giant private equity firm Blackstone. In making the guarantee, Fannie is taking a big leap into the growing home rental market, in which Blackstone is the biggest player. But its also a sign that the true comeback kids are not the Super Bowl champion New England Patriots but Fannie Mae and its cousin, Freddie Mac, both of which were supposed to be left for dead a decade ago.

title: Russians Implicated in Doping Still Compete, Angering Other Athletes
description: Many of the worlds winter athletes, now preparing for the seasons championship events, are frustrated with the response of sports officials to the Russian doping scandal and are wondering why implicated Russian Olympians still turn up at the starting line.

title: A Conservative Climate Solution: Republican Group Calls for Carbon Tax
description: A group of Republican elder statesmen is calling for a tax on carbon emissions to fight climate change.

title: Mother Jones Is Named Magazine of the Year
description: Mother Jones was named magazine of the year on Tuesday for finding new ways to engage audiences and continue its practice of fearless journalism, the sponsors of the National Magazine Awards announced.

title: Lender Deceived Ailing N.F.L. Retirees, Suit Claims
description: The Consumer Finance Protection Bureau and the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman, have sued a New Jersey-based finance company, accusing it of deceiving retired N.F.L. football players who hoped to receive money in the leagues landmark concussion settlement.

title: Is Your Vizio Television Spying on You? What to Know
description: This week, Vizio, one of the biggest makers of internet-connected televisions, agreed to pay $2.2 million to settle charges that it has been collecting and selling viewing data from millions of TVs without the knowledge or consent of the sets owners. The charges, brought by the Federal Trade Commission and the New Jersey attorney generals office, have some serious implications for consumers and smart TV makers.

title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix Australia in February
description: Welcome to Watching, The New York Timess TV and movie recommendation site.

title: Army Approves Construction of Dakota Access Pipeline
description: DENVER  The Army approved the construction of the Dakota Access Pipeline on Tuesday, paving the way for an infrastructure project that has been surrounded by protest and controversy.

title: Alec McCowen, British Actor Who Played Saint and Fool, Dies at 91
description: Alec McCowen, the acclaimed British character actor whose gallery of roles on both sides of the Atlantic ranged from St. Mark to the Fool in King Lear, and from Rudyard Kipling to James Bonds ever-inventive outfitter, Q, died on Monday at his home in London. He was 91.

title: Howard Frank Mosher, Whose Novels Evoked Hardscrabble Vermont, Dies at 74
description: Howard Frank Mosher, whose novels brought to life whiskey runners, trappers, farmers, loggers and other characters of a hardscrabble region in rural Vermont called the Northeast Kingdom, died on Jan. 29 at his home in Irasburg, Vt. He was 74.

title: Mike Pence, the Tiebreaker
description: The modern-day vice president serves primarily as a close presidential adviser and assistant. The vice presidents move from Capitol Hill to the White House has allowed the office to become a significant institution. But this week, Mike Pence reminded Americans of an older role the vice president also sometimes serves: that of legislative officer who can preside over the Senate.

title: Appeals Court Panel Appears Skeptical of Trumps Travel Ban
description: WASHINGTON  A Justice Department lawyer on Tuesday said courts should not second-guess President Trumps targeted travel ban, drawing skepticism from a three-judge federal appeals panel weighing the limits of executive authority in cases of national security.

title: The Accidental Produce Vendor
description: Dear Diary:

title: Is News of Terror Attacks Underplayed? Experts Say No
description: WASHINGTON  Margaret Thatcher famously declared that we must try to find ways to starve the terrorist and the hijacker of the oxygen of publicity on which they depend.

title: Yankees Said to Have Deal With Brewers Slugger Chris Carter
description: That free-agent sluggers like Jose Bautista, Edwin Encarnacion and Mark Trumbo remained unsigned until January was a sign of how depressed the market for home run hitters had become.

title: For-Profit Law School Faces Crisis After Losing Federal Loans
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Toni Valentine, a third-year law student, wanted to know if her school, Charlotte School of Law, was going to close, but it was not telling her.

title: Melania Trump Inc. Imperiled
description: President Donald Trump and his family have done little to assuage concerns that they see the White House as a cash cow. The president has bucked tradition by refusing to release his tax returns. He ignored pleas from the Office of Government Ethics, which called on him to fully divest his holdings in order to avoid dragging mounds of conflicts of interest into the Oval Office. The presidents adult sons have been busy working on projects at home and abroad now that the Trump name opens more doors than ever. Ivanka Trump, the presidents daughter, conspicuously wore a piece from her jewelry line in a postelection interview on CBSs 60 Minutes.

title: Trumps Mix of Politics and Military Is Faulted
description: WASHINGTON  President Trump opened his remarks at MacDill Air Force Base on Monday with a campaign-style celebration of his election victory, citing polls that indicated he had won the votes of a large percentage of the military.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: If we cannot set aside party loyalty long enough to perform the essential duty of vetting the presidents nominees, what are we even doing here?

title: Joyous Africans Take to the Rails, With Chinas Help
description: DJIBOUTI  The 10:24 a.m. train out of Djiboutis capital drew some of the biggest names in the Horn of Africa last month. Serenaded by a chorus of tribal singers, the crush of African leaders, European diplomats and pop icons climbed the stairs of the newly built train station and merrily jostled their way into the pristine, air-conditioned carriages making their inaugural run.

title: Betsy DeVos Teaches the Value of Ignorance
description: Government really sucks. This belief, expressed by the just-confirmed education secretary, Betsy DeVos, in a 2015 speech to educators, may be the only qualification she needed for President Trump.

title: De Blasio May Be Interviewed by Federal Prosecutors on Friendly Turf
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio will probably be on familiar ground when he is questioned by federal prosecutors and F.B.I. agents in New York as part of a sweeping criminal investigation into his campaign fund-raising.

title: Trump Firm Loses Bid to Limit Cleanup Liability for Property
description: South Carolina regulators on Tuesday rejected an effort by the Trump Organization to limit its environmental cleanup liabilities at an industrial site once owned by President Trumps eldest son.

title: Bernie Sanders and Ted Cruz Debate Health Care: Live Analysis
description: Live updates and analysis from Times reporters covering CNNs health care debate between Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

title: White House Weighs Terrorist Designation for Muslim Brotherhood
description: WASHINGTON  President Trumps advisers are debating an order intended to designate the Muslim Brotherhood as a foreign terrorist organization, targeting the oldest and perhaps most influential Islamist group in the Middle East.

title: Drawing a Line From Alternative Theories to Untruths
description: For years, false claims have bubbled from an especially noxious internet crockpot.

title: Yemen Withdraws Permission for U.S. Antiterror Ground Missions
description: WASHINGTON  Angry at the civilian casualties incurred last month in the first commando raid authorized by President Trump, Yemen has withdrawn permission for the United States to run Special Operations ground missions against suspected terrorist groups in the country, according to American officials.

title: Tzvetan Todorov, Literary Theorist and Historian of Evil, Dies at 77
description: Tzvetan Todorov, a Bulgarian-French literary theorist and historian of ideas whose concerns in dozens of books ranged from fantasy in fiction to the moral consequences of colonialism, fanaticism and the Holocaust, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 77.

title: Phil Jackson Lets His Lips Loose as Knicks Ship Keeps Sinking
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Jeff Hornacek and Phil Jackson sat on a bench alongside the court at the Knicks practice complex Tuesday afternoon, some 15 hours after the teams season had reached its low point in a humiliating loss at home to the woeful Los Angeles Lakers.

title: Many Apply, Few Qualify: Canada Rejects Indian Status for Thousands
description: Canada moved this week to revoke the Indian status of thousands of people in Newfoundland who had been recognized as founding members of the Qalipu First Nation band. It is the latest step in a chaotic process to decide who among the sprawling islands nearly 530,000 people should be recognized as Native Canadians.

title: Opening at the Post Office
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  The middle of our solving week is when you can start to expect some real tricks in the puzzle. Clues become vaguer and start to play with words; themes become trickier and take more work to suss out.

title: 2nd Colombian Rebel Group Steps Up to the Table for Peace Talks
description: The National Liberation Army, Colombias second-largest rebel group, joined the government for peace talks in Ecuador on Tuesday, moving Colombia closer to ending a 52-year guerrilla rebellion.

title: Richard Hatch, Who Starred in Battlestar Galactica, Dies at 71
description: Richard Hatch, a veteran actor who played a hotshot pilot in the 1970s science-fiction television series Battlestar Galactica and a political leader in a reboot of the series more than two decades later, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 71.

title: Corrections: February 8, 2017
description: SPORTS

title: Republican Senators Vote to Formally Silence Elizabeth Warren
description: WASHINGTON  Republican senators voted on Tuesday to formally silence a Democratic colleague for impugning a peer, Senator Jeff Sessions of Alabama, by condemning his nomination for attorney general while reading a letter from Coretta Scott King.

title: Five Places to Go in Berlin
description: Potsdamer Strasse, one of the busiest streets in Berlin before World War II, has long been known for its abundance of streetwalkers, sordid sex shops and strip clubs. But in recent years, art galleries have gravitated to this district, abutting a namesake park. And in the last few years, stylish restaurants, cafes and bars have followed. The sex shops are still here, though fading. Now the Potsdamer Strasse crowd has evolved into a hodgepodge of artists, hipsters, older Turks, and the occasional woman sporting stilettoes, fishnet stockings and a come-hither glance.

title: German Automakers Step Up to Silicon Valley Challenge
description: WOLFSBURG, Germany  One of the first things Ole Harms did after taking over Volkswagens new ride-hailing start-up was leave town.

title: Damien Chazelle, La La Land Director, on Californias Allure
description: Damien Chazelle, the writer and director of the musical La La Land, never had any doubts about Los Angeles as an artistic canvas.

title: Time and a Relentless Clock Weigh on Hamburg Soccer Team
description: HAMBURG, Germany  Workplaces often display a particular type of signage: This Department Has Worked __ Days Without An Accident. These notices, with their hopefully ascending numbers, are meant to remind employees of institutional standards, of individual responsibilities, of the importance of mindfulness and consistency.

title: Betsy DeVos, Franois Fillon, Melania Trump: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Good morning.

title: Rarely Seen Photos of Japanese Internment
description: Dorothea Langes photographs of Japanese-Americans interned during World War II capture not only the oppression of a people, but also their struggle to retain their dignity.

title: Rarely Seen Photos of Japanese Internment
description: At first glance, Dorothea Langes photographs of Japanese-Americans, taken in the early 1940s, appear to show ordinary activities. People wait patiently in lines. Children play. A woman makes artificial flowers. Storefront signs proudly proclaim, I am an American.

title: Pentagon Considers Leasing Space at Trump Tower
description: WASHINGTON  The Defense Department may rent space in Trump Tower, where President Trump lives part time, raising questions about a potential conflict of interest because taxpayer dollars could be going directly to his business interests.

title: Whats on TV Wednesday: Manchester by the Sea and More Oscar Nominees
description: Prepare for the Academy Awards ceremony by catching up on two nominees that are now available to stream online: Manchester by the Sea and Nocturnal Animals. Or revisit nominees of the past with The Imitation Game and Catch Me if You Can on TV.

title: Kevin Durant Is Gone. Durant, Okla., Is Sad.
description: DURANT, Okla.  Kelly Green, the mens basketball coach at Southeastern Oklahoma State University, battles relative obscurity by using all the tools at his disposal. Until recently, Green highlighted the campuss unique geography to sell out-of-state prospects on his Division II program.

title: Word + Quiz: meddlesome
Warren Silenced During Senate Debate
description: Senator Elizabeth Warren was accused of impugning a peer when she condemned Senator Jeff Sessionss nomination for attorney general while reading a letter from Coretta Scott King on the Senate floor.

title: Spending
description: Do you have a problem with spending? Can you stick to a budget? Do you save? How aware are you of your habits with money in general?

title: Love, Eventually
description: One night when I was very young, I lay in my bed across from my older sisters and described what I planned to look like when I grew up. My wavy brown hair would be straight and blond. My eyes, now the color of oversteeped tea, would turn blue. I wore a leg brace to bed in those days, a metal rod that buckled with a leather strap below my knee and attached to an ankle-high shoe. Though I felt the weight of this contraption as I spoke, and I knew I limped because the meanest girl on our block had told me, it went without saying that the beautiful future me would walk, and even run, with grace.

title: Republicans Have Lost the Plot on Their Obamacare Repeal
description: President Trump and Republican lawmakers have never been able to explain how they would improve on the Affordable Care Act, which theyve promised to quickly repeal and replace with something better. Now, its increasingly evident that they have no workable plan and might never come up with one.

title: American Universities Must Take a Stand
description: Not since the era of witch hunts and red baiting has the American university faced so great a threat from government. How is the university to function when a presidents administration blurs the distinction between fact and fiction by asserting the existence of alternative facts? How can the university turn a blind eye to what every historian knows to be a key instrument of modern authoritarian regimes: the capacity to dress falsehood up as truth and reject the fruits of reasoned argument, evidence and rigorous verification?

title: Preparing Young Americans for a Complex World
description: Last year, the Council on Foreign Relations and National Geographic commissioned a survey to assess the global literacy of American college students. Over 1,200 people participated; less than 30 percent earned a passing grade. Below are six questions they included, each of which a majority of respondents answered incorrectly. See how you, or your students or children, do. (Answers below.)

title: Connecting Trumps Dots
description: Every day, the presidents behavior becomes more worrying. One day he demeans a federal judge who challenges him; the next day, without evidence, he accuses the media of hiding illegal voting or acts of terrorism. His lack of respect for institutions and truth pours out so fast, you start to forget how crazy this behavior is for any adult, let alone a president, and just how ugly things will get when we have a real crisis. And crises are baked into this story because of the incoherence of President Trumps worldview.

title: A Conservative Case for Climate Action
description: CRAZY as it may sound, this is the perfect time to enact a sensible policy to address the dangerous threat of climate change. Before you call us nuts, hear us out.

title: How the Anti-Vaxxers Are Winning
description: HOUSTON  Its looking as if 2017 could become the year when the anti-vaccination movement gains ascendancy in the United States and we begin to see a reversal of several decades in steady public health gains. The first blow will be measles outbreaks in America.

title: Questions for: Betsy DeVos Confirmed as Education Secretary; Pence Breaks Tie
description: Article: Betsy DeVos Confirmed as Education Secretary; Pence Breaks Tie

title: When Celebrities Ruled the Front Row
description: Photos of Beyonc, Victoria Beckham, Jennifer Lopez and more at New York Fashion Week.

title: Where Have You Gone, Angelina Jolie? Celebrities Vanish From Fashions Front Row
description: Was it just a year ago that Katie Holmes, Jennifer Hudson and Lucy Liu snatched up most of the light and much of the air at Zac Posens fall show? A scant six months later, Mr. Posen was host to a somewhat less lustrous contingent, one that included Malin Akerman, Kelly Bensimon and Olivia Culpo. (Who?)

title: Can a Researcher Studying an Alzheimers Treatment Try It on Himself?
description: Im an older scientist who has spent decades leading a small laboratory at a well-known medical center. Much of our work is purely for the joy of discovery, but we also seek badly needed cures for illnesses. A cure for Alzheimers disease is beginning to look attainable with technology we are pioneering. While investigating genes for early-onset Alzheimers, we invented a gene-transfer method that stopped the brain damage and restored cognitive function. Eureka! Sadly, my doctor has just given me a diagnosis of early-stage Alzheimers. Given that no truly effective treatment is out there yet, can I try dosing myself with our potential cure? Do I have the right, given that I will otherwise die of dementia before a clinical trial could even begin? I plan to do this alone. None of my people will know about it. Its something like a high-altitude, low-opening jump. It is not reversible and may be dangerous. But is it wrong? Name Withheld

title: Willie J. Parker Changed His Mind About Abortion
description: Your book, Lifes Work, is rooted in the fact that you have a moral and spiritual argument in favor of abortion rights, and you talk about your shift from someone who, for religious reasons, didnt want to provide abortion to someone who, for religious reasons, did. Why did you consider that a conversion? I had to come to a crisis moment regarding a religious understanding that left me unable to help women when I felt deeply for their situation. So I needed to convert from a religious understanding that left me paralyzed to act on my deepest sense of connection to one that empowered me to do what I felt to be the right thing. It felt as life-altering for me to move from being unable to do abortions to being able to do them as it did to move from being a nonbeliever to becoming a believer.

title: One Year In, Five Lessons Learned
description: The new year has already brought about significant changes to our world, including the way some of us travel. It also commemorates, less significantly, the one-year anniversary of my taking over the Frugal Traveler column. (No applause, please.) The old clich time flies rings true: It really does seem like yesterday that I wrote my first column from Las Vegas. Ive also spent entirely too much time actually flying this past year. But at least all that airtime has yielded lessons  some more painful than others. Here are five of them, picked up during my travels through 10 countries and a dozen states in 2016.

title: What Jobs Are You Most Curious About?
description: The Times video A Ballerinas Endless Day tells the story of a typical work day for the New York City Ballet dancer Claire Kretzschmar. Watch the video and then decide: Do you think you would enjoy the life of a professional ballet dancer?

title: The Preacher and the Sheriff
description: No one would tell The Rev. Victor White how his son died. Everyone seemed to know  but no one would tell him.

title: What Are the Pitfalls for the Politically Engaged Writer?
description: Does someone want to silence us? Are we at war? Nothing is more exhilarating for a writer than to feel that simply putting pen to paper is an act of courage and a bid for freedom. Remember this novel?

description: SAN FRANCISCO  The workers of Silicon Valley make unlikely revolutionaries. As a group, they are relatively wealthy, well educated and well connected.

description: Some are disarmingly named, like the cutesy Chinese mitten crab. Others have names more indicative of their undesirable nature, like rock snot, an algae that slimes up cool forest streams.

description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  It was the morning after the Golden Globes featuring Meryl Streep and her impassioned remarks, and the visiting stars had turned in their gowns and begun to clear out of town. But Nicole Kidman was at HBOs offices here, taking one last meeting before going home to Nashville.

title: Valley Stream, N.Y.: Neat, Clean and Safe
description: After enduring years of street noise in their apartment in Flushing, Queens, Devanivas Gandham, 58, and his wife, Wilma, 55, began looking for a quieter place several years ago. We saw many, many houses, Mr. Gandham said. And we didnt like anything. Then a cousin who lived in Valley Stream, on Long Island, alerted them to a promising listing.

title: How to Be Mindful While Falling in Love
description: Falling in love is an interesting term. We could say strolling into love or mentally preparing for love but we use the term falling. Its almost like its were throwing ourselves off a cliff and falling without any hope of parachute or sense that we may get wounded along the way. Its simply opening ourselves up to the experience and hoping the other person is also falling beside us.  Lodro Rinzler, author of the new book Love Hurts and co-founder of MNDFL meditation studio.

title: Lessons on Aging Well, From a 105-Year-Old Cyclist
description: At the age of 105, the French amateur cyclist and world-record holder Robert Marchand is more aerobically fit than most 50-year-olds  and appears to be getting even fitter as he ages, according to a revelatory new study of his physiology.

title: When a Teenagers Coping Mechanism Is SpongeBob
description: Parents are often surprised to find that, even late into high school, teenagers return to the books, movies and TV shows they enjoyed when they were younger. When I ask adolescents to share how they like to recharge when feeling stressed, they consistently volunteer that they reread juvenile books like Percy Jackson, rewatch their favorite Disney movies, or mine Netflix for goofy shows like SpongeBob SquarePants.

title: ISIS Detainees May Be Held at Guantnamo, Document Shows
description: WASHINGTON  The Trump White House is nearing completion of an order that would direct the Pentagon to bring future Islamic State detainees to the Guantnamo Bay prison, despite warnings from national security officials and legal scholars that doing so risks undermining the effort to combat the group, according to administration officials and a draft executive order obtained by The New York Times.

title: Draft Trump Order on ISIS Detainees and Guantnamo
description: The Trump White House has developed an evolving series of drafts of a likely forthcoming executive order on handling terrorism detainees. This version, obtained by The New York Times, circulated earlier this week.

title: Meet Aurora of The Sleeping Beauty: Her Native Language Is Classical Ballet
description: Thanks to the composer Tchaikovsky and the choreographer Marius Petipa, the buildup to the heroines entrance in The Sleeping Beauty is the most potent in all ballet. Act I is Princess Auroras 20th birthday. (Many productions change it to her 16th.) The scene begins with the King punishing, then forgiving, some harmless knitting women for using needles at a court that prohibits them. The story has been told already: Aurora will prick her finger and die.

title: A Good Meal Is Hard to Find  at Least on New Yorks Upper West Side
description: Ive been wondering when the Upper West Side was going to complain about me. Until my review of White Gold this week, Id never, in my five years as The Timess restaurant critic, written a full, starred review of any restaurant north of Lincoln Center but south of Columbia University. (I dont count Tavern on the Green, even though the driveway is on the Upper West Side.)

title: Spring Fashions Tough Side
description: Leather accents lend floral dresses a touch of the renegade.

title: Profile in Style: Min Hogg
description: The editor in chief shares her passions and inspirations.

title: The Vibrant Life of a Legendary Design Editor
description: Min Hogg, the founding editor of The World of Interiors magazine, has an individual and rarefied eye. The London native finds beauty in the less obvious, the least glossy and the most idiosyncratic of rooms, chateaus and even potting sheds. From her mother, Hogg inherited a love of faded Oriental carpets, chinoiserie lacquer and the chintz-like colors found in 18th-century porcelain. From her father  who was a personal physician to the queen  she got her innate precision and distaste for pretension.

title: When We Really Did Fear a Bowling Green Massacre
description: THE year was 2012. The place was Bowling Green, Ohio. A federal raid had uncovered what the authorities feared were the makings of a massacre. There were 18 firearms, among them two AR-15 assault rifles, an AR-10 assault rifle and a Remington Model 700 sniper rifle. There was body armor, too, and the authorities counted some 40,000 rounds of ammunition. An extremist had been arrested, and prosecutors suspected that he had been aiming to carry out a wide assortment of killings.

title: New York Philharmonic Announces New Season as It Faces Upheaval
description: As the New York Philharmonic faces its biggest artistic and administrative upheaval in decades, it is announcing its 2017-18 season.

title: Did Kuwait Copy Trumps Travel Ban? Not Quite
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  To the overnight editor at the Arab affairs website, it looked like big news: Kuwait, apparently following the lead of President Trump, had issued a visa ban on citizens from five other predominantly Muslim countries.

title: Supreme Court Nominee Calls Trumps Attacks on Judiciary Demoralizing
description: WASHINGTON  Judge Neil M. Gorsuch, President Trumps nominee for the Supreme Court, privately expressed dismay on Wednesday over Mr. Trumps increasingly aggressive attacks on the judiciary, calling the presidents criticism of independent judges demoralizing and disheartening.

title: His Art Is on the Oxxo Shelves. Keep Your Receipt.
description: MEXICO CITY  It began as a friendly gesture. About five years ago, the artist Gabriel Orozco started printing colorful stickers that mimic the geometry of his abstract paintings: semicircles and quarter-circles in red, gold, white and blue. He plastered the patterns on the back of his iPhone and did the same for friends as small gifts.

title: Why Teen TV Is the Cure For the Prestige TV Blues
description: Margaret Lyons urges viewers to give teen shows a chance.

title: The Cleveland Browns Quarterback Chase Begins (Again)
description: There once was a time when the Cleveland Browns were settled at quarterback. Brian Sipe and Bernie Kosar were steady presences in the 70s, 80s and 90s. Further back, Cleveland relied on the Hall of Famer Otto Graham for 10 seasons, and 10 championship game appearances.

title: Classical Works From the Winter of Life, at Carnegie Hall
description: In a series of three programs presented by Carnegie Hall, the thoughtful young American pianist Jonathan Biss explores The Late Style, that is, music written late in life by various composers. For the opening one, Mr. Biss is joined by the exciting Brentano String Quartet. Works performed will include selections from Bachs The Art of the Fugue (incomplete at his death), Brittens Third String Quartet (composed a year before he died) and Beethovens Piano Sonata No. 32 (the final one). The modernist Hungarian master Gyorgy Kurtag, still active at 90, is represented by selections from Vol. VII of Jatekok (Games) for piano. (Wednesday, Feb. 15, Zankel Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

title: German Expressionisms Other Painter, at Neue Galerie
description: In the same way that Bill Wyman doesnt leap to mind when you think of the Rolling Stones, or Zeppo when you think of the Marx Brothers, the painter Alexei Jawlensky (1864-1941) has never been  at least for most Americans  a household name in German Expressionism, the movement he helped create with his friend Wassily Kandinsky.

title: Jos Mayas Magical Flamenco Tour
description: Flamenco enthusiasts generally mark their calendars for March, when the annual Flamenco Festival comes to New York. But there will be an early treat on Friday, Feb. 17, for those in need of a flamenco fix, when the Spanish dancer Jos Maya presents his Latente: A Flamenco Journey at the Schimmel Center at Pace University. The show, a New York premiere (for one night only), takes inspiration from the great Gypsy singer Juana la del Pipa, who will join the explosive Mr. Maya onstage, along with the vocalists Enrique el Extremeo and Manuel Tae and the guitarist Pino Losada.

title: The Missing Returns to Starz, Raising Questions and Hopes
description: In its first season, The Missing chronicled the anguished search for Oliver Hughes, a 5-year-old British boy vacationing with his parents in France who vanished as his father watched a World Cup game in a crowded bar. Now, in this anthology seriess second installment, which becomes available on Starz on Sunday, Feb. 12, a ghostly young woman stumbles into a German town and announces herself to be Alice Webster, who disappeared more than a decade earlier. She seems changed, enough so that her mother (Keeley Hawes) starts to wonder whether Alice is who she says she is, while her father (David Morrissey) insists on suspending disbelief.

title: Tash Sultana: A Bedroom Busker Leaves Her Nest
description: Tash Sultana, a self-taught singer, songwriter and guitarist, found a local audience by busking on the streets of Melbourne and a worldwide one on YouTube, with songs recorded live and solo in her bedroom. Sometimes, like YouTube hopefuls worldwide, she has performed with just an acoustic guitar. But more often, she has appeared in a nest of guitars, keyboards, amplifiers and gizmos. With looping equipment, she layers guitar and keyboard lines, beats and vocal parts that can be sweetly melodic, raspy and untamed or speedy enough to reach the verge of rapping. She can assemble webs of folky fingerpicking or stack up distorted hard-rock guitars, and she often touches down in reggae. But her most promising songs are the ones in which she is less bound to any genre. (Wednesday, Feb. 15, Mercury Lounge, mercuryloungenyc.com; Feb. 17, Rough Trade NYC in Williamsburg, roughtradenyc.com.)

title: A Man of Good Hope, a Refugee Tale for the Moment
description: It seems as if the entire world is on edge, with xenophobia the word of our times, and though it has been long-planned, the United States premiere of A Man of Good Hope could hardly be better timed. The musical drama, which begins at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Wednesday, Feb. 15, is based on a book (by Jonny Steinberg) about the true story of Asad Abdullahi, born in Somalia and orphaned as a boy, who trekked to South Africa only to face violence there.

title: Humphrey Bogart in Beat the Devil at Film Forum
description: Although it was a resounding flop in its day, John Hustons 1954 comedy, Beat the Devil, has the daffy charm of a movie that feels as it was made up as it was being shot. Preview audiences were baffled by the wisecracking tone of a screenplay credited to Huston and Truman Capote; its been interpreted sometimes as an absurdist spoof of The Maltese Falcon, which Huston had also directed.

title: Yotam Ottolenghi!
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Something Rotten in East Egg? After Historic House Burns, Locals Wonder
description: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y.  There are selling points about this community on Long Islands North Shore that real estate agents whisper to house hunters. This was East Egg in The Great Gatsby. This was where Sinclair Lewis wrote his first novel and John Philip Sousa wrote some of his last marches. This was where Pan American Airways earliest scheduled flights to Europe took off.

title: Daily Report: Germany Prepares for the Future of Cars
description: Germany has long been a leading player in the old economy. Were this 1980, we would call it a titan of industry. And its biggest industry, by far, is cars. Germany makes some of the worlds most popular vehicles, not to mention some of the finest. (Lets forget Dieselgate).

title: Four New Magazines to Know
description: If print is dead, nobody told Francesca Burns and Christopher Simmonds, whose new biannual magazine, PRINT, launched late last year. For us, PRINT was always about a love of magazines, a love of image making; and a desire to create something beautiful, honest and optimistic without an agenda beyond that, says Burns, a contributing editor for British Vogue who met Simmonds (previously the creative director of Dazed and Confused and now an art director for Gucci among others) working on advertising campaigns. The magazine launched in December at Dover Street Market and 10 Corso Como  and sold so quickly it became, according to Angela Hill of the bookseller IDEA, the fastest selling independent magazine launch in the history of their store. The first issue of the oversized magazine comes packaged in a cardboard box with posters, prints and badges. We wanted to create something timeless, that people could come back to and rediscover, Simmonds says. Inside are intimate portfolios from photographers and stylists like Jamie Hawkesworth, Colin Dodgson, Joe McKenna and David Sims  and theres even a photo essay from the singer Frank Ocean. According to Burns, the brief to contributors was simple: to do something personal  to do something that truly inspires the artist and to take time over it. In fact, this is a mantra that Burns and Simmonds took to heart: They pushed the planned release date of the magazine back by a few months. We could take our time, digest it, revisit it and add to it, Simmonds says. The only people we had to answer to were each other. We could do what we felt was right.

title: Hear Igor Levit Play the Diabelli Variations
description: An excerpt from Variations 32 and 33. Mr. Levits favorite six bars occur around 50 seconds into this clip.

description: Operators that organize trips to Iran have begun canceling tours citing difficulty in securing visas for American travelers in the wake of President Trumps executive order barring citizens from seven majority Muslim countries from entering the United States for 90 days.

description: On this weeks podcast, the actor David Oyelowo reads Seeing the World Through My Wifes Eyes, about a man whose other senses become heightened after he loses sight, and whose spouse helps fill in the details he cant discern.

title: Battle to Retake Syrian City Turns Into a Geopolitical Test of the War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A northern Syrian city that is one of the Islamic States last enclaves in the country is under assault by military forces bearing down from all sides.

title: Nevertheless, She Persisted: How Senates Silencing of Warren Became a Meme
description: Some called it a gift to womens rights, and the episode angered many who diagnosed it as a plot to muzzle a vocal senator, Elizabeth Warren, Democrat of Massachusetts.

title: Stephen Sondheim to Receive PEN Literary Award
description: Stephen Sondheim has been awarded the 2017 PEN/Allen Foundation Literary Service Award  making him the first composer-lyricist to win it.

title: Of Thousands of Apps Tested, These Endured
description: The apps business is sometimes like the fashion industry: Fads sweep in and disappear just as fast.

title: 3 Low-Key Labels You Should Know About
description: Spring looks from three emerging New York designers who stand out from the crowd.

title: Beethovens Insane Beauty, According to a Star Pianist
description: It is only three or four years since Igor Levit came to widespread attention, but such is the intelligence and maturity of his pianism that it feels like hes been around forever. With a series of outstanding recordings, political statements and provocative performances  including a staging by Marina Abramovic of Bachs Goldberg Variations at the Park Avenue Armory  he has become an essential artist.

title: Donald Trump, Middle-School President
description: Any parent who has had children in middle school is familiar with their teenage excuses. First, they complain that the teachers are mean and assign too much homework, then that the reading is boring, and then when all else fails, they give you that aggrieved look and whine, Its tooooo haaaaard.

title: Elizabeth Warren Was Told to Be Quiet. Women Can Relate.
description: Was there a woman who didnt recognize herself in the specter of Elizabeth Warren silenced by a roomful of men?

title: Spicer Responds to King Letter on Sessions
description: Asked about a letter that Coretta Scott King wrote regarding Jeff Sessions in 1986, the White House press secretary said he would respectfully disagree with her assessment of Senator Sessions then and now.

title: What Would You Say on the Oscar Stage?
description: The arrival of documentary stars on the red carpet often brings a stiff blast of reality to the fairy-tale concoction that is the Academy Awards.

title: Feting Out of Order Magazine
description: The art-fashion magazine founded by Dorian Grinspan celebrated its fifth anniversary at Mr. Chows.

title: Toasting an Art-Fashion Magazine, Started by a Yalie
description: Perched above the sunken-in dining room of Mr. Chows on Tuesday night, Dorian Grinspan scanned the room and got wistful. Its very humbling, he said. It really is.

title: Ties that Bind, and Fray
description: Welcome to an experiment in journalism and community  a newsletter that will help shape The New York Timess expansion in Australia. Follow along by signing up to receive it by email, and tell us what you think at nytaustralia@nytimes.com

title: Review: Insomniac City Recalls Life With Oliver Sacks
description: INSOMNIAC CITYNew York, Oliver, and MeBy Bill HayesIllustrated. 291 pages. Bloomsbury. $27.

title: William Melvin Kelley, Who Explored Race in Experimental Novels, Is Dead at 79
description: William Melvin Kelley, who brought a fresh, experimental voice to black fiction in novels and stories that used recurring characters to explore race relations and racial identity in the United States, died on Feb. 1 in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: How Senators Voted on Jeff Sessions
description: The Senate voted to confirm Jeff Sessions as attorney general.

title: An Orchestra Triumphs Over Trumps Travel Ban
description: The Budapest Festival Orchestra and its conductor, Ivan Fischer, gave two of the freshest, least conventional Beethoven performances of the season at Lincoln Center this week. Music students unexpectedly rushed the stage to join them in a soaring section of the Fifth Symphony, and incognito choristers popped up among the audience members to sing the Ninths Ode to Joy.

title: Joe Biden Drops by a Fashion Party. The Reason? His Daughter.
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. revealed on Tuesday that for his next act, he would be leading a new initiative at the University of Pennsylvania called the Penn Biden Center for Diplomacy and Global Engagement.

title: Review: In The Lego Batman Movie, Toys and Heroes, Whats Not to Like?
description: As gateway drugs go, The Lego Batman Movie is pretty irresistible. Its silly without being truly strange or crossing over into absurdity. Along the way it pulls off a nifty balancing act: It gives the PG audience its own Batman movie (its a superhero starter kit) and takes swipes at the subgenre, mostly by gently mocking the seriousness that has become a deadening Warner Bros. default. The Lego Batman Movie cant atone for a movie as grindingly bad as the studios Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice, which stars Ben Affleck as the Gotham City brooder, but at least someone on that lot gets the joke.

title: Letters From Jacqueline Kennedy to the Man She Didnt Marry
description: LONDON  In November 1967, four years after her husbands assassination, Jacqueline Kennedy traveled to the temples of Angkor Wat in Cambodia on a much-publicized trip with David Ormsby Gore, a friend of her husband and himself a recent widower.

title: How Do You Save Snow Leopards? First, Gather Their Droppings
description: On the rocky cliffs of the Himalayas, the path to snow leopard conservation is paved in feces.

title: Why the Defense Dept. Is Looking to Lease Space in Trump Tower
description: WASHINGTON  In seeking to rent space in the 58-floor skyscraper that is President Trumps home in Manhattan, the Defense Department is continuing a long tradition of finding a place close to the commander in chief for his top military aides  including the ones who carry the nuclear football of launch codes that follows the president everywhere.

title: A Spring Day in February
description: New Yorkers left their winter clothing at home, if only for a day, as the temperature reached a high of about 60 degrees.

title: Elizabeth Warren, Jeff Sessions: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: CNNs History of Comedy Has Good Timing
description: Its probably just a coincidence of scheduling, but comedy seems to be in an introspective, somewhat defensive stretch. Last summer the documentary Can We Take a Joke?, a theatrical release, explored how hard it is to tell a joke these days without offending someone. Next month, another documentary, The Last Laugh, looks at similar issues. And on Thursday, CNN kicks off The History of Comedy, an eight-part docu-series full of illuminating perspectives on how far comedy has evolved  or, some might say, degenerated  over the decades.

title: Exploitation Draft Plan
description: This Joint Personnel Recovery Agency Draft Exploitation Plan was recently obtained by The New York Times after being declassified in a legal case by former detainees against former Central Intelligence Agency contractors. The plan proposed that a secret military interrogation facility be created, similar to secret C.I.A. prisons that were actually operated.

title: Pentagon Unit Considered Setting Up a Secret Overseas Prison
description: WASHINGTON  As the Central Intelligence Agency was setting up its secret prisons overseas 15 years ago to interrogate terrorism suspects, a Defense Department unit was considering a proposal to establish a secret military prison abroad, according to previously undisclosed government documents.

title: Fury Rises in France Over Accusations Police Beat and Raped a Black Man
description: PARIS  Youths set cars and trash bins ablaze and vandalized buildings in suburbs around Paris on Wednesday, venting rage for the fourth straight day over accusations that police officers had beaten and raped a young black man they arrested last week.

title: Ivanka Trump Reported to Have Stepped Down as Murdoch Trustee
description: Ivanka Trump served for several years as a trustee for a fortune set aside for the daughters of Rupert Murdoch, people familiar with the arrangement said. Her role highlights the close ties between President Trumps family and the family that controls Fox News Channel, The Wall Street Journal and other news outlets.

title: Anderson .Paak, a Singing, Rapping, Drumming Grammy Nominee, Doesnt Fit Into Any Box
description: For this years Grammy Awards, were spotlighting five artists to watch: also see our stories on Kelsea Ballerini and BJ the Chicago Kid, Nineteen85 and Gallant.
