description: Madeleine Hunt-Ehrlich was disenchanted with love until she met her person in fellow filmmaker Jon-Sesrie Goff. They were married Feb. 19 in New York.

title: Sharing Their Visions, Two Filmmakers Find Love
description: At some point, most couples reach that proverbial crossroad where they decide to either put the brakes on their relationship or speed ahead. For Jon-Sesrie Goff and Madeleine Hunt-Ehrlich, that moment arrived in December 2013 as they drove through a snowstorm and Mr. Goffs car started to slide into an intersection at a two-way stop.

description: Updated, 7:12 a.m.

title: My Daughters Silent Virus: Congenital CMV
description: Every morning when I wake up, the first thing I do is I listen. This is a different kind of listening than I did a year ago. I hear the ravens clucking on the roof, the light scratch of rain on the window screen. This is the soundtrack of where we live during fishing season: a small island in Alaska where my husband fishes for salmon four months of the year.

title: Desert X Treats Arid Space as a Rich Canvas
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.  Roaming off-road through sandy, rock-studded terrain in view of mountain peaks and windmill farms, a six-wheeled rover about the size of a milk crate backed up and sped away from its creator.

description: HAMBURG, Germany  Bobby Wood laughed and looked at the ground when he heard the question: Did he think Jrgen Klinsmann was treated fairly in November when he was abruptly fired as coach of the United States national team?

description: One afternoon last summer, a team of prosthetic technicians hovered around Adam Taylor as if he were a racecar in for a pit stop.

title: 12 Great Stories That Have Nothing to Do With Politics
description: Welcome to Our Picks, a guide to the best stuff to read, watch and listen to from around the internet. Check this space for the must-read long-form article, the next great podcast for your commute, the news-making tweetstorm. And yes, were also tooting our own horn here. Well share cant-miss Times stories from the week and reveal some gems you might have overlooked.

title: California Today: In Virtual Reality, Investigating the Trayvon Martin Case
description: Good morning.

title: South Africa Anti-Immigrant Protests Turn Violent
description: JOHANNESBURG  Anti-immigrant protesters led a violent march into South Africas administrative capital, Pretoria, on Friday, and the police responded with rubber bullets, tear gas and water cannons.

title: Middle Schoolers Connect With History Every Day With The Times
description: Its Reader Idea Week on The Learning Network.

title: Lindsey Vonn and Mikaela Shiffrin Withdraw From Ski Race Over Safety
description: The worlds best skiers zipped down the slopes in the Swiss Alps on Friday. But the top Americans, Lindsey Vonn and Mikaela Shiffrin, were not among them. Vonn, Shiffrin and another American, Laurenne Ross, pulled out of the World Cup event because they felt the course conditions were not safe.

title: How Andr Holland Spends the Day: Onstage, and on His Couch
description: Andr Holland can currently be seen acting in three highly praised projects: the Oscar-nominated film Moonlight; the Broadway debut of August Wilsons play Jitney, which had its premiere in 1982; and the Cinemax series The Knick. So it goes without saying that what he really wants to do is produce. Mr. Holland, 37, who grew up in Alabama, recently optioned All Gods Dangers: The Life of Nate Shaw, which won a National Book Award in 1975, and Onaje X. O. Woodbines Black Gods of the Asphalt: Religion, Hip-Hop and Street Basketball. He recently moved from SoHo to Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Steve Miller Sues to Get Out of Buying a House
description: Last month, the musician Steve Miller backed out of a contract to buy a sprawling estate in Dutchess County, N.Y., for $6.7 million when a bank appraised it for $2.4 million less than what he had agreed to pay.

title: Mystery Woman: A Novel Explores the Story of Andrew Wyeths Christinas World
description: A PIECE OF THE WORLD By Christina Baker Kline 309 pp. William Morrow/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

title: A Drifter Gets Rerooted in a Novel of the New West
description: JOURNEYMANBy Marc Bojanowski 247 pp. Soft Skull Press/Counterpoint. $25.

title: How Ed van der Elsken Influenced Other Artists
description: AMSTERDAM  Ed van der Elsken may not have become a household name, but his art has influenced a broad range of photographers, filmmakers and other contemporary artists. Here are three who expressed a direct connection to his art.

title: In Bulgaria, a Businessman Who Talks (and Acts) Like Trump
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria  Veselin Mareshki is a self-promoting tycoon who emblazons his last name on the hundreds of pharmacies he owns across Bulgaria. Hes also a blunt-talking anvil of a populist who preaches patriotism, strict immigration controls, friendlier relations with Moscow and, above all, the need to sweep away the garbage of a corrupt political establishment.

title: The Trump-Like Figures Popping Up in Central Europe
description: WARSAW  Political outsiders across Central Europe, preaching a populist message and promising to overturn the establishment, have felt the wind at their backs since the election of the new American president. We recently profiled one of them, Veselin Mareshki of Bulgaria, who says he sees himself as an anti-establishment candidate like Donald Trump. Many others embrace the connection, too, whether it is their backgrounds in business, their bombastic personalities, or their canny use of celebrity and social media.

title: The Intimate Lens of Ed van der Elsken
description: AMSTERDAM  The Dutch postwar photographer Ed van der Elsken lived with, and through, his cameras.

title: Dont Refight the 2016 Campaign
description: This article is part of the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive more briefings and a guide to the section daily in your inbox.

title: Trumps Blistering Speech at CPAC Follows Bannons Blueprint
description: OXON HILL, Md.  Stephen K. Bannon brought the battle plan. President Trump brought the fight.

description: A judge ruled Friday that one additional woman who says Bill Cosby sexually assaulted her will be permitted to testify at his trial later this year on charges that he sexually assaulted a former Temple University staff member in 2004.

description: TOKYO  At Tsukamoto Kindergarten, an ultraconservative school at the center of a swirling Japanese political scandal, children receive the sort of education their prewar great-grandparents might have recognized.

title: Modern Potboilers at Prada and Moschino
description: It takes a certain amount of gumption for a designer to propose a collection that is the antidote to the unsustainable cycles of consumption.

title: Those Fancy Oscar Gems? You Bet Theyre Insured
description: On Sunday night, a cadre of exquisitely dressed actors will wave and smile their way along the Dolby Theaters red carpet for the 89th Academy Awards. When the women stop, their dresses will almost certainly get mentioned. But so, too, might the jewels around their necks and dangling from their ears.

title: My 10 Favorite Books: Isabelle Huppert
description: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the actress Isabelle Huppert, who is nominated for an Academy Award for her role in Elle. She shares her list exclusively with T.

title: Eight Strappy (and Delightfully Comfortable) Sandals
description: Dorky no more, Teva and friends step up to the fashion plate.

title: Mary Weatherfords Moment
description: Mary Weatherford is known for her moody abstractions of landscapes both natural and contrived, but her latest series  filling both galleries of David Kordansky in Los Angeles and comprising her largest show to date, at least until an upcoming retrospective at the Contemporary Arts Museum Houston  looks inward. It gets to the question of whether your soul is important enough to paint about, says Weatherford, who worked as a bookkeeper for Mike Kelley before getting her first real taste of success in 2012, when she started affixing neon rods directly to the canvas. Her new work continues in this vein, with pale shades of paint layered over metallics and muddy grays. Three double-square panoramas measure nearly 10 by 20 feet. Others are immersive in the scale of their brush strokes. I like the feeling of being smaller than a painting, Weatherford says. And I like the feeling of being inside a wave in the ocean.

title: Illustrated Interview | Anderson Cooper
description: The silver-haired host of Anderson Cooper 360 on CNN, whose book The Rainbow Comes and Goes recently came out in paperback, sketched his answers with a pen in his New York office.

title: Etro: Fall 2017
description: Etro shows its fall looks.

title: In Kim Jong-nams Death, North Korea Lets Loose a Weapon of Mass Destruction
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  For years, North Korea has rattled the world with its nuclear tests and its threats to visit a nuclear holocaust upon the United States. Now, the finding by the Malaysian police that Kim Jong-nam was assassinated with VX nerve agent is a stark reminder of the Norths lesser-known weapons of mass destruction: a stockpile of chemical and biological weapons.

title: Women Do Like to Compete  Against Themselves
description: About 10 years ago, when we were both Ph.D. students at Harvard, we were invited to participate in an unofficial and largely secret wrestling tournament organized by a fellow student. The idea was to showcase a handful of competitive wrestling matches between graduate students in different departments to an invitation-only audience. Space and gym mats were rented, a referee and a master of ceremonies were appointed, and monetary bets were placed on individual matches. Each wrestler had his or her own costume, entrance song and fan base. Alcohol flowed freely among the spectators.

title: In London, the Rise of Old-Fashioned Fashion
description: London has a reputation for breeding young designers who generally make clothes of the unwearable variety. Their work is called avant-garde, meaning dresses are made of Saran Wrap or chicken feathers with leather pointy-shouldered blazers and mismatched shoes (although the much-copied Phoebe Philo of Cline showed the latter for spring/summer 2017, so maybe the lopsided look is about to go mainstream.)

title: Trump vs. the Judges, Part III
description: SEE YOU IN COURT, THE SECURITY OF OUR NATION IS AT STAKE! Donald Trump wrote on Twitter.

title: Economists Have Been Demoted in Washington. Thats a Bad Idea.
description: Academic economists have received a demotion. The Trump administration has been filling out its cabinet and, unlike in the Obama administration, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers will not be part of it.

title: A Fearless, Ferocious Violinist Takes New York
description: Of the many excellent, polished violinists in the classical world, there is only one Patricia Kopatchinskaja. She takes the standard repertory and makes it seem vividly, sometimes harrowingly new. Take, for example, her recording of Tchaikovskys Violin Concerto with her fellow provocateur Teodor Currentzis and his ensemble Musica Aeterna, a raw, fearless, ferocious take on whats often a comfortable chestnut.

title: Noname, Still Unsigned but a Presence
description: The Chicago rapper Noname, a disciple of spoken word and Def Poetry Jam, has nimble wordplay and a warm, unruffled voice that work even better over beats. After appearing as a guest on Chance the Rappers two breakthrough mixtapes, she released her own debut project, Telefone, as a free download last summer, blending what she has referred to as sunny Los Angeles instrumentation and grim Chicago subject matter. Too many babies in suits, Noname raps over the cooing of a child on Casket Pretty, about her citys plague of gun violence. But there is hope in the music, too, and in her onstage demeanor, best exemplified by a Saturday Night Live cameo alongside Chance in December; an unsigned rapper gliding onto the national television stage, Noname gave a master class in poise, delivery and self-assuredness. (Thursday, March 2, at Le Poisson Rouge; 212-505-3474, lpr.com)

title: Duets in Some of a Thousand Words Say It All
description: Some dance presentations of solos and duets are little more than flash and glitter. Some of a Thousand Words, a new program by Wendy Whelan and the choreographer and dancer Brian Brooks, is quite another matter. In 2015, Ms. Whelan, an eloquent former New York City Ballet ballerina, offered a program by several choreographers, and Mr. Brookss contributions attracted special attention. Now they reveal how the interactions of two dancing people  their lifts, falls, changes of weight and entangling of bodies  can reveal inner feelings as well as technical prowess. Live music will be provided by Brooklyn Rider, a quartet that champions contemporary music; composers include Philip Glass, John Luther Adams, Tyondai Braxton, Jacob Cooper and Colin Jacobsen, a violinist with the quartet. (Tuesday, Feb. 28, through March 5 at the Joyce Theater; 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

title: The Forgotten Legacy of Herbert Lehman
description: On election night 1928, after his first campaign for public office, Herbert H. Lehman and his wife left a note on their bedroom door for their children: Dont wake us. Daddy has been beaten, but he doesnt feel badly.

title: In Tickled, on HBO, a Wild Rabbit Hole of Hunks and Feathers
description: Tickling as a pastime and even a fetish, sure. But as a sport? David Farrier, a New Zealand journalist with a lust for the weird and bizarre, knew he had a story when he happened upon an online video for competitive endurance tickling, in which hunky young men were tied to a bed with their clothes on and tickled  and paid for it by a company called Jane OBrien Media.

title: An Iraqi-Born Artist Who Speaks Through Arcs of Calligraphy
description: The Iraqi-born artist Hassan Massoudy, who is based in Paris, draws on his classical training in calligraphy to create vibrantly colored oversized letters evocative of traditional Arabic script. Having formerly produced headlines for Arabic magazines as a student, Mr. Massoudy now bases his compositions on texts from Eastern and Western poets, authors and philosophers. And at a time of uncertainty for immigrant artists, he is having his first New York solo exhibition, at Sundaram Tagore Chelsea. The show, Words, Breath, Gesture, features more than 25 works on paper as well as several paintings on canvas that Mr. Massoudy has created with his own tools and inks. (Through March 25; sundaramtagore.com.)

title: Series of Star-Spangled Satires at IFC, Amid a Nascent Presidency
description: If ever an era was in dire need of pointed commentary and point-blank humor, it is our fractious present. So hail the IFC Center for the series Autocratic for the People: An Unpresidented Series of Star-Spangled Satires. And for Mike Judges crude but prescient Idiocracy (2006), playing Friday, March 3, through Sunday, which nails our media-addled-and-addicted culture with a precision often inducing queasiness.

title: The Light Years, at Playwrights Horizons, Examines the Shadows of Showbiz
description: The Debate Society is a minor miracle: a small, scrappy theater company whose years of producing quiet gems go against the grain of a culture driven by hype, stars and spectacles. As it has graduated from cramped downtown and Brooklyn spaces to Off Broadway theaters with nicely appointed lobbies, this company, which specializes in haunted and intricately detailed worlds, now presents a play set in the shadow of show business on a mass scale: The Light Years.

title: Hipster Cop Retires. The Nickname Still Applies.
description: In the history of the New York City Police Department, members have stood out for heroic arrests and exemplary leadership, but there has been only one Hipster Cop.

title: Amid a Flurry of Oscar Events, Celebrations of Black Girl Magic
description: Im good, but just today I realize Im a little nervous, Viola Davis told the Bagger on Wednesday night at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel, during Alfre Woodards annual Oscars Sistahs Soiree.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: Danica Patrick, Stuck in the Pack, Makes Changes for a Pivotal Season
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Danica Patrick is not a fan of average. Never was.

title: Stranger Than Reality?
description: One could be forgiven for thinking that now isnt the moment to try to outdo real-life Washington in fiction. But close observers of the political scene are getting into the thriller game.

title: The Posters of La La Land
description: The movie musical La La Land has been dealing in multiples since its premiere last year. It has collected multiple critics awards, Golden Globe wins and Oscar nominations (a record-tying 14). And its advertising campaign has made use of multiple posters.

title: Trump Immigration Policies Pose Conflict for Police in Sanctuary Cities
description: President Trumps sweeping new immigration policies  which include efforts to shine a harsh national spotlight on cities that released undocumented immigrants who went on to be accused of serious crimes  are sharply increasing the legal and political risks confronting local law enforcement officials.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Impossible Dream

title: Review: Ariana Grande Asserts Herself With Stilettos and a Soaring Voice
description: Ariana Grande asserts herself by acting like she doesnt have to. Her Dangerous Woman Tour, which came to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, is a show of confidence, prowess and aplomb. Nothing to prove and/Im bulletproof and/know what Im doing, she sang in Dangerous Woman, the title song of her 2016 album and the concerts bluesy finale. The concert was full of songs about a young womans needs and prerogatives, mostly lusty ones, delivered with peppy choruses and without shock value or shame. Ms. Grande often sings about the overwhelming strength of temptation and how much pleasure there is in giving in.

title: What Happens Next (or Doesnt)
description: There were things my husband brought to the marriage that had to be gotten rid of. The grandfatherly forest green recliner. Certain blocky-looking shirts bought for him by his mother. The occasional phone call from an old girlfriend. There was one item that was a keeper, though, a volume called Plotto: The Master Book of All Plots.

title: Automatic Update Headaches
description: Q. Microsoft seems to update Windows 10 constantly and it results in computer freezes and other issues for me. If I wanted to switch, is there a real advantage to Apple software as opposed to Microsoft?

title: Caitlyn Jenner Slams Trump on Transgender Order: See You in Court
description: Caitlyn Jenner, perhaps the most influential transgender activist in the country, joined a growing chorus of critics who have denounced President Trumps decision to rescind protections that allowed transgender students to use the bathroom of their choice.

title: George Saunders, Famous for Futuristic Short Stories, Hits No. 1 With a Historical Novel
description: Mourning in America: Could Joe Biden have been the next Abraham Lincoln? That thought came to mind recently thanks to George Saunderss debut novel, Lincoln in the Bardo (new at No.1 in hardcover fiction), which centers on Lincolns sorrow over the death of his young son. Biden, you may remember, opted not to run for president shortly after his son Beau died of cancer in 2015  a wrenching and understandable decision, of course, but one cast in retrospective relief by the suggestion in Saunderss novel that private grief made Lincoln a better public servant. What moved me about Lincolns arc during his presidency, Saunders told me via email, was the way that the burdens of the office  the floundering war effort, intense public criticism, the mistakes he made that were costing so many lives, the death of his son  beat him down and made him sorrowful, but also, almost causally, seemed to expand the reach of his empathy, so that, by the end, it included soldiers on both sides and the millions of Americans being enslaved by other Americans. It seemed to me that the empathy was somehow a byproduct of the sorrow  a burning-away of his hopes and dreams that resulted in a kind of naked seeing of things as they really were. For me, the book was about that terrible conundrum: We seem to be born to love, but everything we love comes to an end. What do we do with that? How can we keep going and live positive lives under that shadow? I came to understand Lincoln as someone so beat down by sadness and loss that he developed a sort of crazy wisdom  as if, in sadness, all of the comforting bromides that normally keep us from the harsher truths were denied him. Empathy might even thrive best in this state, where the easy comforts are denied us. Conversely, empathy doesnt do well in a climate of fear or anxiety, when one forgets the particular and individual and, in a panic, begins theorizing about whole groups of people without knowing many of them.

title: In a House of Whimsy, Room for Mischief
description: Dave Malloy, the composer and lyricist of the Broadway musical Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812, lives in a one-bedroom rental in Park Slope, Brooklyn, with large windows, high ceilings, a small office, two fireplaces (they dont work, but are charming nonetheless) and many toys and stuffed animals. Those expecting an embarrassed disclaimer about the playthings will be disappointed.

title: What I Love | Dave Malloy
description: Whats essential to Dave Malloy, the composer of Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812, and his wife, the writer Eliza Bent? Stuffed animals.

title: Academy Awards 25 Years Ago: Not So Different From Today
description: From the moment the host Billy Crystal was wheeled onstage wearing a straitjacket and a face mask  la Hannibal Lecter in The Silence of the Lambs, viewers knew the 1992 Oscars were not going to be normal.

title: Shopping for Console Tables
description: Console tables are frequently among the last pieces of furniture to be added to a room. They sometimes get neglected, said Tara Bernerd, an interior designer in London. Very often, its on that second look, after a room is filled, she added, that the need for one becomes apparent  because they serve a variety of purposes.

title: Little Credit History? Lenders Are Taking a New Look at You
description: About 45 million Americans lack traditional credit files, and the federal government is looking into whether alternative credit scoring models could bring more of these consumers into the financial mainstream.

title: In a New History, Russias Revolution Through Expat Eyes
description: CAUGHT IN THE REVOLUTION Petrograd, Russia, 1917  A World on the Edge By Helen Rappaport Illustrated. 430 pp. St. Martins Press. $27.99.

title: Daily Report: Another Day, Another Uber Scandal
description: As bad weeks ago, starting last weekend Uber has had one of the worst in tech industry annals.

title: An Ethnographer of Cancer Care for IBM Watson
description: Hannah Graffeo, 26, is a design researcher at IBM in New York.

title: Womens Fashion Shows: Prada, Fendi, Emilio Pucci, Moschino
description: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2017 collections that were presented in Milan on Thursday.

title: How to Make Eyes Pop  Without the Appearance of Liner
description: Backstage at Etros fall/winter 2017 show, the makeup artist Mark Carrasquillo enhanced models complexion with lots of moisturizer  the backbone of any natural beauty look  and a smudge of blush. And because he wanted eyes to pop but didnt want the appearance of obvious makeup, he used the ol water line trick: Carrasquillo edged the inside of the upper eyelid, right along the water line, with a pencil (MAC, in Teddy  a slightly metallic, deep brown tone) before curling lashes and brushing mascara onto the upper tips. Since its not on the skin, you dont see the line of the pencil, said Carrasquillo, noting that usually eyeliner is only applied to the lower water line. You still get this darkness to the eyes, this added attractiveness, but without a cosmetic feel.

title: In an Ancient Burial Place, 3 Centuries of One Womans Descendants
description: In a really small room in a really big house, archaeologists found the body of a 40-year-old man. They knew he was special. He was buried with a conch shell trumpet and large shells from the Pacific coast, far from this crypt in the 650-room building known as Pueblo Bonito in what is now called Chaco Canyon, in New Mexico. He was adorned with more than 11,000 beads and pendants made of turquoise and more than 3,000 made of shell. But if he was special, he was just the bottom layer.

title: Tell Us  What Should Conception Cover Next?
description: The New York Times would like to hear your ideas for continued reporting about families, relationships, parenting and children.

title: Anti-Immigrant Protests in Pretoria
description: Anti-foreigner protesters led a violent march in Pretoria, South Africa, on Friday. The police responded with rubber bullets, tear gas and water cannons.

title: Paperback Row
description: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Doctors Consider a Last Best Hope for Obese Teenagers: Surgery
description: If all goes well, Aliayha Carrasco-Garcia will have an operation next month that will change her life. She will shed many of the 240 pounds that now burden her 5-foot-2 frame. Like many who have bariatric surgery, she has tried diets and exercise to no avail. Surgery is her last best hope.

title: There at the Creation: Profiles of Seven 20th-Century Artists, All Women
description: IDENTITY UNKNOWNRediscovering Seven American Women ArtistsBy Donna SeamanIllustrated. 455 pp. Bloomsbury. $35.

title: Mushroom and Squash Tart
description: Sweet butternut squash balances the earthy roasted mushrooms on this airy pizza tart.

title: A Vegetable Tart, but Nothing Too Dainty
description: Savory tarts can be dainty things, eaten on your finest china with a pinkie in the air.

title: Amazon Deforestation, Once Tamed, Comes Roaring Back
description: COLONIA BERLIN, Bolivia  A few months ago, a representative from Cargill traveled to this remote colony in Bolivias eastern lowlands in the southernmost reaches of the vast Amazon River basin with an enticing offer.

title: Tods: Fall 2017
description: The luxury leather shoe and accessory house presents its fall designs.

title: In Walden Video Game, the Challenge Is Stillness
description: Its certainly a long way from Grand Theft Auto.

title: Bow and Cooper in Children of Divorce: Poor Little Silent Rich Kids
description: The past is a foreign country, the British novelist L. P. Hartley wrote. They do things differently there. In silent movies, you might say they act differently. The look is all.

title: More Homes Sold, Fewer Available
description: According to data from the National Association of Realtors, the number of existing homes sold in 2016 was the highest in a decade: 5.45 million single-family houses, townhouses, condominiums and co-ops were sold, up 3.8 percent from 5.25 million in 2015. The previous high, in 2006, was 6.48 million.

description: UPDATE AND APOLOGY: Sloppy and insensitive about nursing. Apology here.

title: A Belgian Artists Graphic Memoir Looks at the Sometimes Tortured Course of Love

title: Ex-Kentucky Governor to Give Democratic Response to Trump
description: WASHINGTON  Former Gov. Steve Beshear of Kentucky, a senior Democrat best known for putting the Affordable Care Act into effect in a deeply conservative state, will give his partys response to President Trumps address to Congress on Tuesday, Democratic congressional leaders announced on Friday.

title: A Croque-Madame Dressed Up With Crab
description: Every Francophile has eaten a croque-monsieur, the French rendition of a grilled cheese sandwich. You can get one in any cafe or buy one from a bakery, ready to heat and eat. It is, for all intents, a hot ham and cheese sandwich, the top spread with a layer of creamy bchamel sauce and grated cheese, then broiled until golden and bubbly.

title: What You Should Read About Last Nights Heartbreaking Nashville Episode
description: To state the obvious, you should not read this article if you have not yet watched the Feb. 23 episode of Nashville.

title: Consignors Complaints Pile Up Against Vintage Car Dealer
description: Several readers have written recently expressing concern about the evident tension between the Haggler and the dull and windy nitwit whose name is attached to this column. The Haggler has, for a long time, tried to make it clear that this nitwit is not to be confused with the Haggler, but the message does not seem to be getting through. If anything, the nitwit

title: Hygge Is Where the Heart Is
description: Baby, its cold out there. And I dont mean the weather. This, the most divisive political season in memory, has truly been the winter (and spring and fall and summer) of our discontent. Many of us are struggling. Its not even a question of loving our neighbor at this point; its more a question of tolerating him.

title: French Election: The 5 Leading Presidential Candidates
description: PARIS  Amid electoral upheavals around the world, including Brexit and the election of President Trump, France will hold a first round of national voting to elect a president on April 23.

description: Its a big city, with plenty to do, see, hear and watch. This guide is a sampling of cultural highlights taking place in New York this weekend and over the week ahead. And theres much more where these came from.

description: TELL ME EVERYTHING YOU DONT REMEMBER The Stroke That Changed My Life By Christine Hyung-Oak Lee 262 pp. Ecco/HarperCollins Publishers. $27.99.

title: Policing Flint
description: Step inside a police department struggling with budget cuts and public distrust.

description: To the Editor:

title: Did Someone Say Tax Code Rewrite? Lobbyists Scramble
description: WASHINGTON  The homebuilders lobby fears that an ambitious rewrite of the entire tax code will stifle the housing market. Retailers fret that it will make the cost of their imports soar. For charities and their representatives, the worry is that donations will be stunted, plaguing nonprofit groups that serve the neediest Americans.

title: Fleeing U.S. for Asylum, and Handcuffed in Canada
description: They drag their luggage, carry their young children in their arms and join hands to help one another over rough terrain and along snowy roads. They are immigrants, refugees and asylum seekers who are streaming across the border from the United States into Canada in higher numbers.

title: Polluted Streams
description: To the Editor:

title: Church Abuse in Australia
description: To the Editor:
